In a statement, Mr Sanders' national policy director Josh Orton said: Washington's foreign policy establishment has been consistently wrong, and that a Sanders administration would begin to repair the damage done by Trump.Mr Sanders, 78, was strongly influenced by the Reagan-era US&nbspinterventions in Latin America, which appalled many liberals. Those years also influenced his broader approach to the region, which stands apart from many Democrats. Mr Sanders was at odds with many in the party last year, for example, when he refused to call Mr Maduro a dictator, even as he made critical comments about the authoritarian socialist leader.His comments about Mr&nbspMorales, whose success lifting Bolivians into the middle class made him an iconic figure among socialists, also stood out. At a Univision forum, Mr Sanders praised Mr Morales for addressing poverty and empowering indigenous people. He added that it was fair to question whether he should have stayed in power so long – almost 14 years – but it was a far less critical approach than other Democrats took towards a man whom many viewed as increasingly authoritarian.Mr Sanders has been accused by members of both parties of not being tough enough on repressive socialist regimes. He's not going to pretend we face remotely equivalent threats from left-wing authoritarianism than from right-wing authoritarianism, said a senior Sanders aide, speaking on the condition of anonymity to be candid.When he ran for president four years ago, Mr Sanders often appeared unprepared for a rigorous foreign policy debate. Facing opponent Hillary Clinton, a former secretary of state, he often sidestepped questions about specific global challenges.&nbspFollowing his loss, Mr Sanders sought to shore up his foreign policy credentials. After the 2016 election, he hired Matt Duss, who has helped the candidate with his foreign policy chops. Now his top foreign policy hand – and seen inside Mr Sanders' world as a potential future national security adviser –Mr&nbspDuss rose from blogging about policy to helming the Foundation for Middle East Peace.&nbspIn the years after his loss to Ms Clinton, Mr Sanders delivered some lengthy speeches on foreign policy, including one at Westminster College in Missouri, where Winston Churchill gave his famous Iron Curtain address.&nbspThat 2017 Sanders speech encapsulated much of his thinking on world affairs, people close to him said. In it, he tethered his foreign policy vision to his populist domestic agenda, declaring, We cannot convincingly promote democracy abroad if we do not live it vigorously here at home.Mr Sanders argued that the events of the past two decades have discredited the notion that the US&nbspshould use its military might to shape the world to its liking. He decried US&nbspinterference in Iran and Chile in the 20th century. He underlined the need for alliances to confront adversaries such as North Korea. On a smaller scale, he touted the value of partnering with a sister city in Russia when he was mayor of Burlington, Vermont.&nbspMany Democrats remain unimpressed. On the campaign trail, Mr Sanders has increasingly clashed with Mr Biden, who touts his extensive foreign policy experience in the Senate and Obama administration.David Lammy, the&nbspBritish MP, who has gotten to know Mr Sanders in recent years, noted that Sanders' views would fit more comfortably in a typical European centre-left party. Whether he were in Germany or France or the UK, of course, Bernie, his politics would be very familiar and probably quite mainstream, Mr&nbspLammy said.He added, Clearly, in the US&nbspcontext, it has been a slightly different experience.While Mr Sanders' unorthodox views make some Democrats nervous, the most pointed hostility comes from Republicans. Asked what he thinks of Mr Sanders' foreign policy platform, senator&nbspThom Tillis said, A disaster.&nbspStanding next to him in an elevator in the Capitol Building was senator&nbspRick Scott&nbspwho chuckled and interjected, Does he have a foreign policy?&nbspYet this is a time of foreign policy upheaval in both parties. Mr Trump himself has upended decades of Republican thinking, praising figures such as North Korean leader Kim Jong Un while questioning the role of Nato. A populist non-interventionism is surging in both parties, championed by figures such as representative&nbspTulsi Gabbard and senator Rand Paul.That has given Mr&nbspSanders a sometimes surprising array of foreign policy partners on Capitol Hill. He teamed up with senator Mike Lee, a conservative Republican from Utah, on a measure to end US support for the Saudi-led military campaign in Yemen. Their legislation passed the Senate and forced Mr Trump to issue his second veto.&nbspSanders introduces law to stop Trump from starting war with IranOn Saturday, Mr Lee signed onto Mr Sanders' bill to prevent Mr Trump from deploying funds for military action against Iran without congressional approval.Other alliances have been more controversial. Representatives Ilhan Omar and Rashida&nbspTlaib, who have endorsed Mr Sanders for president, strongly support the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions (BDS) movement to pressure Israel over its policies towards Palestinians.&nbspMany Democrats and Republicans, including some who have criticised Israeli policies, object to the BDS movement as going too far. To me, BDS has no place, said senator Ben Cardin, formerly the top Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.&nbspMr Sanders himself does not support the BDS movement. But he has been a vocal critic of Mr Netanyahu, and he has said he is willing to make foreign aid to Israel contingent on fostering more peaceful relations with Palestinians, a condition many Democrats and Republicans are unwilling to impose.&nbspWhen it comes to international trade, Mr Sanders opposes an emerging US&nbspdeal with Mexico and Canada, arguing that it does not go far enough in protecting American jobs. The deal has the support of the union AFL-CIO and&nbspElizabeth Warren among others on the left.To some moderate Democrats, including senator&nbspJon Tester of Montana, Mr Sanders' message at times can resemble the current president's promises to avoid needless wars. Kind of like Trump? Mr Tester mused in a brief interview at the Capitol. Mr Sanders' identification as a democratic socialist is something he has to overcome in his pitch to be commander in chief, Mr Tester added.Trade politics also ided Mr Sanders and&nbspBarack Obama. He may have more differences with Obama on foreign policy than Trump, is the great irony, said John Cavanagh, who has known Mr Sanders since 1991 and directs the Institute for Policy Studies, a liberal think tank. Both he and Trump can sit down with workers in the Midwest. It's just that one does it in a racist and xenophobic way.But Mr Sanders has his stark differences with Mr Trump as well. The senator from Vermont was a lonely voice opposing the most recent defence spending bill. And Mr Sanders favours international diplomacy to tackle big issues such as the Paris climate accord.Until recently, Mr Sanders' proposals have been overshadowed by his sweeping domestic agenda. But the US&nbspkilling of Iranian military commander Qassem Soleimani prompted Mr Sanders to amplify the linchpin of his foreign agenda: his long-standing opposition to US&nbspintervention abroad.&nbspNews of the airstrike came late 2 January, after Mr Sanders had spent the day campaigning in Iowa. Inside a restaurant at the Doubletree Hotel in Cedar Rapids, Mr Sanders huddled with aides including campaign manager Faiz Shakir and his deputy, Ari Rabin-Havt, according to a person with knowledge of the situation. Mr&nbspDuss, the foreign policy adviser, joined by phone. Together, they crafted a statement calling the killing an assassination and drew a connection to the instability caused by the Iraq War.&nbspIt gives me no pleasure to tell you at this moment we face a similar crossroads fraught with danger, he said the next day during a town hall meeting at the National Motorcycle Museum in Anamosa, Iowa, delivering a speech he wrote and then revised on the drive from the hotel, according to the aide with knowledge of the situation.For some at the town hall, his aversion to military conflict resonated. We've been through this in the past, said Thomas Wiand, 51. We went through unnecessary wars continually.Against all odds, it looks like Bernie Sanders might be the nomineeOthers were more cautious. Sometimes you have to go and do what needs to be done to correct the situation, said Craig Bruxvoort, 62, a grain farmer who applauded Mr Trump for ordering general Soleimani's killing.&nbspThose who have worked with Mr&nbspSanders on foreign policy describe him as methodical and inquisitive. Suzanne DiMaggio, a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment who is advising Mr Sanders on Iran, recalled him asking specific questions about the consequences of general Soleimani's killing.&nbspA lot of the questions focused on the internal political dynamics in Iran: What are the likely scenarios that will now emerge? How will it affect those who are moderates in Iran? Ms DiMaggio said.&nbspBen Rhodes, who served as deputy national security adviser under Mr Obama, remembered briefing Mr Sanders on the Iran nuclear deal for about an hour,&nbspas the senator fired questions his way.A more vivid memory for Mr Rhodes was how Mr Sanders was affected by talking to veterans and family members of soldiers killed in combat.&nbspI remember him telling me once, he said, 'Obama doesn't get enough credit for how many troops Obama took out from Afghanistan,' said Mr Rhodes, who has offered informal advice to Mr Sanders and other candidates. title: brexit timeline january 31
story: Heres the latest on the key dates before Johnsons vowed January  Brexit date.The UK is set to quit the EU on January ,  - you can follow the new years Brexit timeline here.This comes after Brexit day was delayed three times.The United Kingdom and the EU have negotiated a transition period which could be extended until December , should both sides agree. The plan to leave the EU on October  floundered when Boris Johnson’s three-day timetable to push the Withdrawal Agreement through Parliament was rejected by MPs.The UK has now been granted a delay until the end of January after the EU accepted Britain’s request for a “flextension”.Britain voted to leave the EU in a referendum held on June , .However, the result of the vote only became legally binding through a piece of legislation called Article .The bill was signed by then PM Theresa May and delivered to the European Council President on March , .This triggered a two-year exit process, with Britain set to leave the EU by March , .May had a deal agreed with Europe - but MPs rejected Mays meaningful vote three times, leading to May requesting an extension.More than three years on, and its still unclear when Brexit will actually be delivered.Heres how we get to where we are - amendments, bills and all.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Heres who is most likely to replace him according to the bookies.Labours Jeremy Corbyn is yet to stand down as party leader, but candidates are already lining up to take over.Corbyn has said he will not stand at the next General Election - set to be in May .Here are the odds according to Bet on January :Keir Starmer is the current favourite to take over from Jeremy Corbyn.A YouGov poll revealed a third of the party favour more moderate Keir over other wannabe leaders.The confirmed candidates so far are Clive Lewis with four nominations, Rebecca Long-Bailey with  nominations, Lisa Nandy with , Jess Phillips with , Emily Thornberry with ten and, in line with predictions, Keir Starmer with .The race will officially kick off this year, with the next boss set to come into office by March.Jeremy Corbyn said he would stay in place while the party decides who will take the crown.There is no deputy leader to fill the position after Tom Watson stood down as MP earlier this year.The partys general secretary, Jennie Formby, wrote to the national executive with a recommended start date of January .Wannabe candidates are already hard at work bidding for the top spot.The stakes are high for the party after Corbyns failure to secure dozens of safe seats across the country and the alienation and disillusionment of many voters.A new leader will aim to claw back Labours losses following the  December election.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince harry meghan exiled plan b
story: But what happensthe wheels fall off the Harry and Meghan love wagon  What happens to Harrythings go wrong  Does he have a Plan B The Duke and Duchess have a rosy vision of the future. It will be a le away from prying eyes where they make their own money and live le as they want, freed from duty.But, critics say, Meghan may soon tire of her husband along with the corner she’s painted herself into by giving up her film star le to become a royal.Harry, taken away from the world he grew up in and separated from his friends, may find le far away in Canada tougher than he imagined.If the worst comes to the worst — and The Sun hopes it doesn’t — what then Can Harry come home and be forgiven  Will the Queen excuse him and put his failed relationship down to a temporary infatuation Will the taxpayer continue to fund him while he takes time finding a new home and another job The answer to all these questions is probably No. When Harry goes, the door will slam shut behind him. He will become an outcast.You need look no further than the Duke and Duchess of Windsor to see just how roughly the Royal Family can treat those who desert them.When King Edward VIII abdicated in  at the age of  he was sent into an exile from which he never ed.He thought that time would be the great healer but he was wrong. He lived out the rest of his days in Paris, longing to come home.He hadn’t reckoned on how tough his brother — the new King George VI, the Queen’s father — could be.The Duke thought he’d get a generous financial settlement. He didn’t. He thought he’d be able to keep his royal protection officers. He couldn’t.He thought he’d be found a job befitting his status once the dust settled. No dice. He lived in hope that he could die in the country he once ruled. Not a chance.Soit all falls apart and Harry thinks he can come home again, he’d better check the history books.And Meghan should take a good look, too. The Windsors lived in France surrounded by smart acquaintances but with their friends far distant.The couple were living in a vacuum of their own making.The Duke discovered he’d made an enemy of his brother, the King, because of the damage he’d done to the royal institution. Harry may find out William feels the same.Although at present it seems unlikely, Harry could be stripped of the “His Royal Highness” tag on the basis that he no longer represents the family.AndHollywood grabbed the chance to put a newly free Meghan on the big screen — one of her unachieved big ambitions — the House of Windsor would be wise to quickly withdraw her HRH tag before further damage is done.It requires no Act of Parliament to do this, just a nod from the Queen. And with a hugely disgruntled William and Charles prompting her, it could just happen.Then there’s the question of baby Archie. Will he in the future be allowed to claim kinship with the Royal Family, living back in the country where he was born Or will he become just another celebrity kid in a Tinseltown mansion without a sense of purpose or direction GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says harry meghan bankrolled
story: Their plan for global domination as Instagram’s “progressive” royal power couple looks fatally flawed.First it relies on them still being bankrolled by an increasingly enraged public — as they magnanimously “work to become financially independent” despite already being worth sums most of us cannot imagine.Second, because when they finally deem their wealth vast enough to cut that umbilical cord, their livelihood will still centre around their image as senior royals . . . a role they have quit.The idea of them busily enriching themselves by flogging their part-time royalty to advertisers will disgust taxpayers — both on principle and because this ­entitled pair will never refund a penny back into Treasury coffers.The UK public will justiably demand they be cut off at the ankles, stripped of the titles on which they trade.What then for plain Meghan and Harry Wales, the narcissist formerly known as Prince Who will listen then to their vapid sermons  They might fancy themselves as the new Clintons or Obamas — but they have not earned their  or status.They were born into it, or married into it, but gave it up when it all looked too dull, too hard and not enough fun.Diehard fans will stick by them. They will doubtless make big money. But the firestorm of criticism they have ignited here will become an inferno.It is a disastrous mess and may get worse. The couple’s assumption about the public continuing to fund round-the-clock security in Canada looks ­premature — and must be reviewed.Harry is worth £million, Meghan another £million. How much richer must they be before they pay that bill WHY is the Government still so coy about celebrating the moment of Brexit Leaving the EU at pm on January  will be a huge milestone in our modern history, the end of our -year membership and the starting gun for negotiating a lucrative new era of trade.The Sun wants Big Ben to bong. We want bunting, fireworks and, yes, commemorative Royal Mail stamps.We understand the feelings of Remainers. But there were plenty of them among the million who voted last month to “get Brexit done”.The big day is less than three weeks away following its final passage through the Commons on Thursday.How typical of Labour, given one last chance to vote for the deal securing our exit, to remain childishly opposed to it.Defeated in the referendum, crushed at the election. title: boris should not bend opinion
story: Previously, in weeks where Brexit legislation was before the Commons, discussion was dominated by whether or not the Government had the numbers to win the vote and how it should respondit did not.This time there was barely a mention of Brexit despite the votes on it this week. .Pretty much all Boris Johnson had to say on the matter was to urge ministers to, “banish Brexit”, from their lexicons after January , when the UK leaves the EU.Boris wants ministers to stop talking about Brexit once the UK has left as he doesn’t want the trade negotiations with the EU to dominate British politics in the way that leaving has since the referendum. He wants to show voters that the country has moved on and the Government is once more focusing on the domestic issues voters care about.But however much he tries, it will be hard to make these talks boring. They are important and there is already DRAMA BREWING.Boris saw the new Commission President Ursula von der Leyen in Downing Street this week. The pair got on well in their hour-long meeting. They both want these talks to be less acrimonious than the orce negotiations both want a more cordial tone.The pair reminisced about the school they had both attended in Brussels. Unlike Eton, it didn’t have playing fields, and until Johnson arrived the only game in the playground was marbles. He introduced some more rough and tumble.No were pleased that von der Leyen, rather than the more confrontational Michel Barnier, took the lead. As one No source points out, the EU loathed the lack of clarity and authority under Theresa May: She wasn’t clear what she wanted and it wasn’t certain that she could deliver what she wanted.With Boris and his new majority it is very dferent. He was able to point von der Leyen to the Tory manesto’s commitments on the future trade deal and say this was his mandate and that he was determined to deliver it.Yet despite the pair’s attempt to maintain a friendly tone, there are already tensions. Boris is irritated that the EU keeps saying it is nigh-on impossible to negotiate a full trade deal by December , despite having signed up to a political declaration that commits it to trying to do just that.The DANGER is that the EU thinks that under time pressure Boris will bend, that he will either extend the transition period — something he has repeatedly promised not to do — or drop his commitment to breaking away from EU rules and regulations.Boris is determined not to do either of these things. He doesn’t want to extend and believes in the value of the UK having the right to do things dferently.Both sides have frequently misunderstood each other in this process. Both sides must now realise that the other means what it says. Unless they do, there is going to be an almighty bust-up and no trade deal at the end of all this.THERE will be a National Security Council meeting later this month to decide whether or not to allow the Chinese company Huawei to be involved in the construction of the UK’s G network.This is an issue of fierce debate in Whitehall. Under Theresa May, it led to the then Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson’s sacking from government.Hawkish figures inside government fear No is leaning towards allowing Huawei’s involvement. One complains that Downing Street’s timetable for the technology’s roll-out is, “not realistic”, but that this time pressure means it will need Huawei involved. However, I understand that the Americans are pushing very hard for the UK to bar Huawei.One senior US government national security figure has been in London this week to lobby directly on this point.Before he makes a decision on Huawei, Boris Johnson should consider the damage it could do to Britain’s most important security relationship – the Five Eyes intelligence-sharing agreement with Australia, Canada, the US and New Zealand.Eventhe UK thinks it can manage Huawei’s involvement,our allies do not then we shouldn’t proceed. It is simply not worth the risk of undermining such a vital alliance.Don’t expect his approach to change. His holidays will be far more glam than Cameron and May’s were.THE most common reason British governments fail is that the Prime Minister and the Chancellor fall out.If No and the Treasury – the most powerful department in government – aren’t on the same page, nothing gets done.Boris Johnson and Sajid Javid are determined to avoid this fate. In the run-up to the Budget on March , there will be a huge effort to make sure that the Treasury and No work together.One Johnson ally tells me the two men will have a Budget-focused meeting at the start of each week to make sure they are in agreement on the key issues.Then their teams will meet again mid-week to assess progress. Javid, whose job is safe in the coming reshuffle, is determined to show that the Treasury is capable of delivering on Boris Johnson’s agenda of levelling up across the country.Those close to him are confident that they can put meat on the bones of No’s plan.AT Cabinet this week it was impressed on ministers that one of the most important events this year is COP, the climate change conference the UK is hosting in Glasgow in November.The UK Government wants to use the event to show how Britain can lead on clean growth post-Brexit.I understand there will be a steady drum beat of announcements on this front throughout the year: The Tories want to show they are helping create new green-collar jobs.They also hope that by holding the event in Scotland, they can emphasise the benefits of the Union.THE Labour leadership contest has yet to catch fire.The Tories are not particularly concerned about any of the candidates.Though there is some hesitation about how they would handle PMQs with Jess Phillips, who likes to make very personal attacks on Boris Johnson.But the most interesting candidate in the race is Lisa Nandy.She seems to have the clearest understanding of why Labour lost.Her bid is starting to have faint echoes of David Cameron’s successful tilt at the Tory leadership in .GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum 30000 lottery jackpot text just 10
story: Dawn Rivers was thrilled when she got a message with a £ sign, and assumed she had scored the jackpot prize.But the -year-old was thoroughly let down after finding out the true winning sum, after planning how to spend her windfall.A technical fault meant the text alert she got didnt show the amount she had won - which turned out to be only a tenner.Dawn, from Bourneville, Birmingham, told Birmingham Mail: Ive won £ before,its a tenner they just put a little message to say youve won £ its gone in your bank.You know when you think you have won something and your mouth dries up  Thats what happened.I was so excited to have a bit of money to play with, I had already spent it in my head.Buying some extra things for the house. I told my daughter I would help her out after Christmas.I got dressed every morning waiting for the postcode lottery to come to my door.It makes you feel sick when at the end of it you havent got it. Thats whats really annoyed me.The Peoples Postcode Lottery said it never made reference to a big win, and had included a link detailing the £ win in the text.A spokesman said: A spokesman for People’s Postcode Lottery said: “The winners of our biggest prizes, such as Postcode Millions or £, a day, are always contacted in person and may also be visited by a Postcode Lottery ambassador. This is reflected in our marketing.“Text alerts are only used to noty players of smaller wins.There was no error in the drawing, distribution or notication of prizes. A technical fault meant that in this instance, the value of the £ prize was not stated within the text itself but recipients could still click the link included to confirm the value of their win.“Our customer experience team confirmed the situation on two occasions and we remain in contact with the player concerned.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 100 year old tortoise saved species 800 babies
story: Diego the super tortoise came to the rescue of his fellow creatures by mating with hundreds of partners on the Santa Cruz Island, off the coast of Calornia.However, after over  years of back-breaking work, it is time for the centurion to retire and travel home to the Galápagos Islands.The breeding programme that made his libido world famous has produced over , hatchlings, around  per cent of which call Diego their dad, according to The Galápagos National Parks service.Park director, Jorge Carrion, told AFP: He’s contributed a large percentage to the lineage that we are ing to Española.There’s a feeling of happiness to have the possibility of ing that tortoise to his natural state.He willto Española in March after a stint in quarantine.Diego was brought to San Diego Zoo in the s where he stayed as one of the zoos main attractions until , when the plight of Chelonoidis Hoodensis tortoises, which are unique to Espanola, was first recognised.Conservationists were amazed when lustful Diego got to work.The -stone, cm-long lover and another male were initially placed with twelve females, which back then was the entire remaining population of the species. But since then around , baby tortoises have been born.He was previously described as a very sexually active male reproducer by Washington Tapia, a tortoise preservation specialist at Galapagos National Park.The species is now on its way to reaching its historical record of ,.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queen landmark meeting heated atmosphere
story: To my knowledge, something like this has never happened before in terms of what it is all about and that it is happening so quickly.This is the ultimate summit between the head of state, the two heirs to the head of state and the sixth in line to the throne.With Charles and Diana’s orce, the Queen wrote to them inidually saying they had to start talking and sort orce proceedings. She didn’t meet them.Even the abdication of Edward VIII over Mrs Simpson, together below, was at Government and Church level.To have documents prepared in advance does not surprise me. The Queen has said she wants this sorted out and without delay.Many have called this an abdication and in one sense it is. title: see back of harry and meghan
story: What a waste of the mountain of goodwill there was towards that happy, glamorous couple who wed on a sunshine-soaked day in Windsor in . And what a waste of their chance to play a key role in helping our Royal Family prosper after the Queen is gone.And what a waste of Harry and Meghan’s unique chance to be a living, inspirational representation of the multiracial country in which we now live. How quickly the shine has come off the golden couple.Less than two years after that wedding day, Harry and Meghan are scurrying off to an ill-defined “progressive” new le in Canada.Butthey have been unhappy with their royal roles, they have brought it on themselves. This much-loved couple have always been too thin-skinned for their own good.They have always been hysterically touchy when justied criticism came their way, such as when they lectured about climate change while reclining on private jets.The criticism was nothing personal. Hollywood stars get called out for climate hypocrisy. Do Harry and Meghan really imagine we will just tug our forelocks as they fly around the world in private jets while talking like Greta Thunberg in a tiara Harry and Meghan are never satisfied with anything less than unconditional deference. They apparently loathe royal le, yet demand to be treated like royalty.They have demonstrated an epic sense of entitlement, such as asking the taxpayer to pick up the £.million builder’s bill for doing up their home, Frogmore Cottage.Their great self-pitying delusion is that the wicked British media has it in for them. But it is not the media that caused Meghan so much excruciating embarrassment.It is largely her own dysal family and their indiscreetly flapping cakeholes, especially her dear old discarded dad Thomas Markle and her loony half-sister Samantha. Harry and Meghan’s self-pity is astounding.“Never complain, never explain,” has been the motto of the modern Royal Family. It has worked rather well.But place Harry and Meghan in front of a sympathetic camera crew, such as when ITV’s Tom Bradby trailed them on their tour of South Africa, and they can’t stop whining. Even when surrounded by victims of rape and landmines, they managed to feel sorry for themselves.“Not many people askedI’m OK,” Meghan complained in the Third World. There has not been a royal couple with such a staggering lack of self-awareness since Marie Antoinette and King Louis XVI of France. And look what happened to them.Harry and Meghan owe their mega-celebrity totally to their connection with the Royal Family. Their superstardom has nothing to do with Meghan’s acting career. Their lives of unimaginable luxury are funded in large part by the British taxpayer.The average couple spends just under £, on their wedding. Harry and Meghan were said to have blown £MILLION. Yet they do not appear to have a grateful bone between them. They seem incapable of counting their multiple blessings.Even now, after handing in their royal resignation, they give every indication that they want all the privileges of royal le with none of the obligations. They want to have their Eton mess and eat it.Harry and Meghan’s security alone currently costs around £, a year, paid for by the politan Police — which means paid for by the British taxpayer. Get the Mounties to start paying for it.And can we finally nail the great lie that Meghan has been persecuted in the UK because of her mixed race  When she first appeared, Meghan was a hurricane of fresh air. The British looked at her and it was love at first sight.This weary, ided, Brexit-battered nation was delighted to have an injection of Hollywood glamour. And millions of Brits now live in mixed-race families. There was real delight to see the Royal Family catching up with the rest of us.Among those crowds at Windsor on their wedding day I saw families of every race and creed under the sun who were ecstatic to see the Royal Family becoming less white, more inclusive, more representative.Harry and Meghan have drawn criticism because of their total lack of self-awareness. Both of them are independently rich. Harry is worth around £million after inheritances from his mother and the Queen Mum.Prince Charles gives him £million every year. Meghan made around £million from her role in long-runningTV legal drama Suits.Yet this fabulously wealthy couple have been happy to let others — the British taxpayer, Prince Charles, the Queen — pay their way in their gilded world.Six weeks, which is theof time that Harry and Meghan have just spent in Canada, is a very long time to be away from home.Unless, of course, “home” doesn’t feel like home because you feel criticised for everything you do and wear, your family – on both sides – are a nightmare and you are constantly judgedby people who have never met you and never will.I should imagine that in this case, Canada seems like a very good place to call home. So, who can blame Meghan and Harry for deciding to leave the UK behind to get away from it all, and maybe staying away from here in the long-term I have a lot of respect for the couple for ploughing their own furrow and walking their own path.Honestly, I couldn’t be happier for Harry, who has experienced so much sadness, that he has met a woman brave enough to suggest doing things a bit dferently.Although they are currently making bold statements about giving up the taxpayer-funded Sovereign Grant, they show no sign of being willing to pay for their own security, or their own flunkies, or offer the taxpayer a rebate on those reported £million nuptials.There has never been even the slightest hint of gratitude. There has never been any indication that they — this rich, pampered couple with a beautul baby boy who will never want for anything — realise how lucky they are.So Harry and Meghan are not the only ones with mixed emotions today. There is real resentment that Harry and Meghan have caused distress to our Queen and it will not be easily forgotten or forgiven.The Queen has a -year-old husband who has recently been in hospital. She has a son mired in a squalid sex scandal. And she is  years old. Who the hell do Harry and Meghan think they are This feels like an abdication with a taxpayer-funded safety net. The couple plan to “step back as senior members of the Royal Family” but show no inclination to give up the privileges and pay days that come with the job.They say they want to “work to become financially independent”. But between them they are currently worth around £million. Why not pay their own way NOW Are they really suggesting that they turn their backs on this nation while asking it to foot their bills  It looks like it. The British taxpayer will continue to stump up for their phenomenal security bills. Harry’s daddy will cough up for much .So you can’t help wondering how intelligent they really are, this TV soap actress and a man who left Eton with two A-levels— a school where my dog could get four A-levels.Do Harry and Meghan really think they have had a raw deal  Are they that stupid  There is no republican movement in this country.The Queen has reigned far too well for far too long —  years on the throne next month — for anti-monarchy sentiment to develop.The Queen has spent her entire le placing public duty above private happiness.She has been the stable, stoic centre of this nation for so long that she has single-handedly made losing our monarchy unthinkable.Yet when a spokesman for anti-monarchy pressure group Republic demanded Harry and Meghan make a clean break, I found myself nodding in agreement with every withering word.“Theyhave said that they will dip in and out of royal duties as it suits them but won’t stop taking money until they find other sources of income,” said Republic’s Graham Smith.“To suggest they’re not already financially independent is incredibly crass and belies a sense of entitlement and lack of self-awareness common among royals.”This republican is right. If Harry and Meghan want a new le hanging out with the Clooneys and striking deals with Apple, they should fund it themselves.As they say in North America, do it on your own dime. Give up the HRH titles. Stop leeching off your royal status.They will be a footnote in the story of our Royal Family, Meghan the Wallis Simpson of the st Century, Harry another Duke of Windsor who believed exile with his American orcee would make him happy.The Royal Family is not all about them.The Queen will be an impossible act to follow. But the photograph of Queen Elizabeth smiling proudly with the next three generations of future kings — Princes Charles, William and George — suggests our Royal Family will last for at least  years after Netflix has cancelled The Crown, evenone day Meghan gets to play herself.The succession is assured. Decent men will wear the crown. And Kate is great. But let history record that no royal couple was ever as adored as Harry and Meghan.It is astonishing — and unbelievably sad, perhaps even tragic — that millions of us will be happy to see the back of them.Astrological patterns repeat in families through generations, just as it is doing with Meghan and Harry.Edward VIII, who wed American orcee Wallis Simpson, put love before duty, and planted a karmic seed that is at the root of what is unfolding now. It can be likened to a virus that has been lurking in the Royal household and is now being re-activated by Harry and Meghan.So what comes next  Uranus, the planet of shock-waves, moves to confront the Sun in Aquarius on January  and forms a clash with the New Moon on the th.There is likely to be a stinging backlash as all the remaining senior family members have their roles shaken up.Meghan will create a power couple that flourishes by spring with a number of initiatives. By December , another baby announcement is likely.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: blind eye iran no longer option
story: No president could ignore the killing of US contractors, the invasion of its embassy in Baghdad, the threat to the lives of American service personnel.If that threat was imminent, he was right to act. We would have done the same to protect British servicemen and women. In fact, as Britain’s Defence Secretary I did exactly that, with the full support of Prime Minister David Cameron.Let’s not forget that every country has the right to self-defence.Of course, nobody wants this crisis to escalate. Indeed Iran’s retaliation has been noticeably limited so far.But the chorus for “de-escalation” carries risks too. Iran has been attacking Western shipping, including capturing a British tanker. Iran has fired missiles at Saudi oil refineries.Iran continues to wage proxy wars in Lebanon, Syria and Yemen. Through its militias, Iran continues to destabilise neighbouring Iraq.At some point, somebody had to draw the line. Qasem Soleimani was no hero or statesman. He directed terrorist attacks across the Middle East.Thousands of Syrians, Iraqis and Yemenis died as a result. Iranian dissidents, too, were brutally suppressed.The roadside bomb-making he sponsored killed many of our brave servicemen in Iraq. As Prime Minister Boris Johnson reminded us, he had the blood of our soldiers on his hands.Has Trump’s strike weakened the case for Western intervention  It is worth remembering our troops and those of the US are in Iraq at Iraq’s invitation.Since , we have helped lead an international coalition of more than  countries to support its fragile democracy and liberate that country from the terrorist death-cult of Daesh Isis.And thanks to precision strikes by the RAF and the training by the British Army of thousands of Iraqi troops, Daesh has lost the pernicious grip it once had.Defeating Daesh isn’t just a matter of helping a friend in need or of standing up for human rights. Mercully, we have stopped Yazidi women from being raped, prisoners being burnt alive, gay people being thrown off buildings and Western hostages sadistically executed.But tackling Daesh terrorism is also vital to protect our own way of le here in Western Europe.Islamist fundamentalism needs to be defeated, whether in Mosul, Raqqa, a Paris suburb or on London Bridge.So yes, let’s continue to work with our allies to persuade Iran’s revolutionaries to take a dferent path.Saudi Arabia, the other Gulf countries and even Russia all have roles to play in getting Iran back to the negotiating table.After the appalling shooting down of the Ukrainian airliner, let’s try to show the Iranian people their government needs to be more truthful and more open, that there is a better future beyond the mullahs and the republican guards.But diplomacy alone will not be enough. We have to protect our national interests too. Trump’s strike is a stark reminder that in the end, we must all stand up when those interests are threatened so directly.First, we must persuade other European navies to work with the US and our own Royal Navy in patrolling and protecting convoys through the Strait of Hormuz.This is a vital choke point for Europe’s trade and energy. The gas and oil we need this winter pass through it.It is ludicrous that some Nato allies won’t work with American ships for fear of upsetting the mullahs in Tehran.This has to be a US-led international operation.Second, we need a better nuclear agreement with Iran. It was right to try to halt their nuclear programme. But the previous deal wasn’t comprehensive — it didn’t even cover missiles — and it completely failed to constrain Iranian misbehaviour in the region. If anything, Iran used the access to new finance that deal released to step up its proxy wars in Yemen and where.A new deal should ensure full oversight of all Iran’s nuclear activities by the International Atomic Energy Agency, and only allow Iran back into the international markets when its civil nuclear programme is in complete compliance.Third, we have to step up our campaign against terrorism.Outside the EU after Brexit, we will still need to share intelligence and work together with our European partners to identy new attacks. But our closest ally in the battle to protect our values will always be the US. We may not always agree with Trump’s tactics but we shouldn’t ignore that he has finally cut through the illusion — Iran’s current regime is not our friend.Iran will certainly have learned a lesson from President Trump’s decisive action. But I hope we will do so too.Turning a blind eye to those who foster international terrorism is no longer an option for any of us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what you do after mistakes important
story: But in all honesty, what really matters is not so much what happened but how we respond.Take the young woman who was in court this week after drunkenly propositioning male passengers on a flight from Abu Dhabi to Manchester. She askedthey wanted to join her in the “mile-high club”, then attacked cabin crew who refused her more alcohol.Demi Burton tried to headbutt and kick six crew members and passengers who tried to restrain her before she was arrested when the plane landed.In court, the -year-old claimed she had been drinking because she has a fear of flying and said this behaviour is out of character, which may be true.Her defence lawyer Martin Callery said: “She is thoroughly ashamed of herself . . .  and utterly embarrassed at the way she behaved.”But that is certainly not the impression she conveyed outside court, where she gleefully flicked obscene hand gestures at photographers.No doubt she stopped smiling when she heard she had been sentenced to six months in prison. Personally, I’m not sure how effective prison is. But the problem with reckless behaviour is that you have to face the consequences.And I really hope for Demi, this is the moment she gets her le back on track. We all make mistakes. It’s what we do afterwards that defines us.It would be easy to assume that Demi is a hopeless case. But she is young enough to turn her le around, to work hard, do better and see this rock-bottom moment as a catalyst for change.And then something good will come from what is a very low moment in her le. We don’t have to look far for examples of people who have overcome lapses or mistakes before going on to succeed.Take Robert Downey Jr, who went from drug addict to one of Hollywood’s highest-paid actors. Or Elton John and Robbie Williams, both of whom have overcome major drug issues before enjoying renewed stardom, fatherhood and, more importantly, a good le.While it is not the same as a drunken mistake, anyone who has made it in business will have a good few failures under their belt — whether it is a dodgy commercial decision, plain bad luck or a company that has gone bust.It is not what happens to us in le but what we do next that counts. So I am guessing that, from her cell, Demi might be reflecting on what she might do dferently when she gets out. Andshe isn’t, she should be.Because it is the getting back on the horse that counts, evenit means resisting the urge to go back to bed to hide. No one is perfect. No one gets through le without messing up or things going wrong.Before success, you will get temporary defeat or total failure. The key to getting through it is resilience. And one of the best gts you can give a child is to encourage them not to give up.By the way, I speak here from experience. Like any businesswoman, I’ve made some mistakes and had my fair share of knocks.There are some that I have managed to turn to my advantage and others that I have had to chalk up to experience.The key thing is that I have learned from what went wrong, then moved on. That experience has allowed me to create a mini-manesto on how to fail how to respond to setbacks and failure, which I’ll share here now:Give yourself time to recover and reflect. Force yourself to take small steps to get back on the horse. Do not accept failure. See it as a step on the journey towards success.Remember that challenging and dficult moments are what help you grow bigger or better. Without them, you would stay the same.The only people who haven’t experienced setbacks are people who are too scared to try. So “failure” is often a sign of bravery. Hold your head up high at all times.Try your best and be proud to do so, eventhings don’t always work out the way you want them to. Remind yourself: “Where there is a will, there’s a way.” And as they say, the best thing about the future is it comes one day at a time.ANOTHER new year, another month of looking at photos of scantily clad people on beaches in sunnier climes and asking myselfI am the only person who is not on the beach.This is the time of year for massive bikini-body and holiday FOMO.But let us all take heart that it is also, oh joy, the time of year for elasticated waists hidden under chunky knitwear.Personally, I am more than happy to swap the beach for nothing to shave and no stomach to suck in. Bliss.I’M sure parents everywhere were shocked to read the story of the son who bullied his mother and stepfather so viciously he has been jailed for three years for his controlling and coercive behaviour.When Nicholas Hazell, , of County Durham, went back to live with Judith Ridley, , and her reverend husband Stephen, , after losing his job, he made their lives hell.Hazell, above, created a “horrendous atmosphere” at the family home and flew into a petulant ragehe didn’t get his own way, Durham Crown Court heard.Among his worst outbursts were when Hazell threw his mother into a chair and spat at her while holding a screwdriver to his stepfather’s throat. He also told them: “I am a master of bullying.”It sounds horric.I feel so sorry for his mum, who must be devastated that her little boy turned into a cruel bully as an adult.I dont do needles when it comes to my face.  Lasers, facials, peels . . .  sure. But needles are another story entirely.If you are willing to take the chance of injecting poison into your face, at the very least you want a predictable result. And in my experience, you don’t get it.Who wants eyebrows at the top of their head, lips that come into the room before you do, or a forehead that doesn’t move  Not me, that’s for sure. However . . .This week I read that not only is the gorgeous Abbey Clancy having micro-Botox injections, hyaluronic acid fillers and vitamins, she is doing it with TWENTY needles at once.Abbey, , is having something called an aquagold facial, so called because each needle is covered in -carat gold. The marketing blurb claims this treatment will reduce pores, blur out fine lines and leave your skin with a vibrant glow.Some might say this is a slippery slope to the stronger stuff but Abbey looks amazing.  So it has to be worth a try, don’t you think I HAD to laugh at the photos of the BBC newsreader whose dress, which had burst open minutes before going on air, was cobbled together from behind by quick-thinking colleagues.  Liz Beacon’s outfit was patched up with gaffer tape and bulldog clips.I used to believe what I saw on TV. But since filming The Apprentice, I know all too well that all is not necessarily what it seems.Two examples spring to mind. First, the countless times I have been filmed in the boardroom with a smart jacket on top and leggings or even pyjama bottoms and slippers under the boardroom table.Second, and worse, the time I somehow forgot to bring a bra on a day I was wearing a white blouse.Luckily, a kind crew member who is roughly the same size as me lent me hers.  And the show, as it always seems to do, went on.I WAS appalled to read about the private Islamic secondary school that has been “unlawfully segregating” boys and girls for all activities except weekly assemblies, according to a stinging Ofsted report.One of the teachers theretold pupils “university is not for females”, according to the report. title: british doctors paid thousands secret virginity repair surgery
story: A secretive “revirginisation” industry in Britain is thriving at the expense of women who fear rejection from their traditional families.It is believed hundreds of girls are travelling from abroad to London where they endure the invasive hymenoplasty procedure, paying thousands of pounds at a time.The procedure more commonly known as ‘hymen repair’ aims to create the illusion of an “unbroken” hymen, traditionally considered to be a mark of virginity.The operation, which takes less than an hour and is performed under local anaesthetic, involves constructing a layer of skin at the entrance to the vagina that tears when a woman first has sexual intercourse.The majority of women targeted by the “revirginisation” industry are young Muslims from Middle Eastern and Asian families under pressure to be “untouched” when they marry.Extramarital sex, or zina, is forbidden by the Koran.An investigation by the Sunday Times revealed at least  private clinics are offering hymenoplasty, mostly in London.Some charge up to £, for the surgery and lure vulnerable patients with advertisements that promise the surgery can “restore your innocence” and are “one hundred percent safe”.One such private clinic, Regency International, in north London, appeared top of Google’s search results with ads reading: “Become a virgin again. Hymen repair surgery to get your virginity back!”Another clinic, the Gynae Centre, in central London, recommends having the “small” operation because “the hymen is considered a token of virginity and for cultural and religious reasons can be an important factor in a new marriage. In many cases marriages are even annulledthe hymen is torn.”The Sun has approach Regency International and Gynae Centre for comment but are yet to receive a response.“Virginity repair” surgery is legal in the UK.Most hymenoplasty procedures are carried out privately in clinics that are not required to collate statistics, making it impossible to know how many take place.However charities believe hundreds of patients are undergoing the procedure in the UK every year.The Sunday Times reported some clinics have seen soaring demand, with one reporting a fourfold increase in inquiries in the past five years.About , people searched Google for hymenoplasty and related terms in the UK last year.Outraged campaigners have accused the clinics of capitalising on the fears of patients.Guidance from the General Medical Councilsays that before undertaking any procedure practitioners must obtain a patient’s “informed consent”, which “may not be validit is given under pressure or duress exerted by another person”.Dr Leila Frodsham, from the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, said hymen repair perpetuated “harmful myths” about virginity.Dr Frodsham said: “I think people would be surprised to know this is going on.”“There are a lot of people making a lot of money out of very vulnerable women.”She also said that requests for the operation posed an “ethical dilemma” to medics.Dr Frodsham added: “It is very dficult to think that it’s justied to operate on somebody as part of a religious practice.”“There is no benefit other than demonstrating that you’re a virgin on your wedding night.”Mohammad Masood, director of MAS Gynaecology, said requests for the procedure at his Harley Street clinic had risen four-fold since .He said his patients typically found him online and were “almost exclusively Muslim”.He explained: “Some of the girls are going through situations wherethey don’t bleed there is stigma and there’s no way the marriage will survive.”“Their wellbeing hinges on their virginity and not bringing a bad name to the family.”In every case, Mr Masood said he arranged a discreet consultation with the patient to determine their suitability for the procedure.He also offered follow-up counselling, but “usually they do not want contact. They will say, ‘Do not ring at all. Do not use phone. Just email.’”About a third of his patients travel to the UK, particularly from Iran, Turkey and other countries in the Middle East, where the procedure is available but considered taboo.Charities and medical experts have called for closer regulation of the virginity industry in Britain.As well as medics offering the surgery, the internet is awash with “articial hymen” kits containing fake blood and vaginal tightening pills that can be inserted before sex.

title: karen matthews seen without engagement ring
story: The -year-old had told pals she broke off her wedding plans to Paul Sanders after details about his vile past emerged.The handyman had previously served time for abusing a vulnerable girl and was forced to sign the sex offenders register.A source claims the pair - who are allegedly like loved-up teenagers - are simply lying low until things die down.She reportedly told a friend she was looking toher £. title: keir starmer posh remainer leader
story: It was this “Posh Trot” Remainer who drove a bulldozer through Labour’s so-called Red Wall and cleared the path for Boris Johnson’s invasion of its northern heartlands.It was Starmer’s campaign for a chaotic second referendum that persuaded millions of working-class supporters to vote Tory for the first time and condemn Labour to the political wilderness.Not surprisingly, Starmer’s critics now wonder why this proven loser is in pole position to run their party.Some point the finger at Gordon Brown quietly rallying supporters to the cause.The ex-PM and his protegé have been close since Starmer’s controversial reign as Director of Public Prosecutions from  to .Starmer, despite his reputation for defending human rights, is not above sly ploys.There is nothing wrong with being wealthy — except among the Momentum voters he needs to seize Labour’s crown. Perhaps this explains why his Wikipedia entry has just been doctored to delete his status as a “millionaire”. Not me, guv, protests Starmer.He is also weirdly reluctant to declare where he stands on the political spectrum. Is he a Corbynite or a Blairite or a bit of both  “I don’t have the names of former leaders tattooed on my head,” snfs the man named at birth after the first leader of the Labour Party.This knight of the realm, who played violin at fee-paying Reigate Grammar School alongside Fatboy Slim, claims a humble background as the son of a toolmaker.“I know what it’s like,” he insists, asraised in a cardboard box.Well, I went to the same school when it was a “bog-standard” state grammar. My father was a journeyman upholsterer. It didn’t give me any special insights.Starmer boasts in his new campaign video about picket-line stints alongside down- trodden Wapping printworkers — against my boss, Rupert Murdoch, a hate figure on the Left.This chameleon politician was dubbed a “Sir” on the recommendation of Gordon Brown, a title he discourteously declines to use because it invites contempt among those with a vote.His citation was for “services to law and criminal justice”, after a five-year term as DPP.At about the same time he was parachuted into Parliament as MP for rock-solid Labour Holborn and St Pancras, in London.It is here that self-respecting Labour voters should pause and reflect.Many believe these political plums were reward for the longest, costliest and perhaps most spiteful criminal persecution in history — ordered by Sir Keir Starmer.His new leadership video slyly refers to this time, apparently to boost his scourge-of-capitalism image among the “comrades” — even though politics should play no part in a DPP’s decision-making. In a travesty of justice, he rammed two dozen innocent journalists through Old Bailey trials on trumped-up conspiracy charges — a medieval catch-all which even the Crown Prosecution Service admitted was “an extremely dficult and rarely visited area of the law”.The prosecuting counsel was given a flea in his ear for “chopping and changing”, the charges against the journalists.The trials ended with acquittals all round, an admission that “no crime may have been committed” and this rebuke from the Lord Chief Justice:“What concerns me is the freedom of the Press and the desire of officials to contain information.“We must ensure the Press is protected — we can’t use criminal sanctions to undermine their position.”The defendants were all journalists on The Sun or the News of the World — then seen by the Left as fair game.The trials followed The Sun’s decision to switch its support from Gordon Brown’s floundering regime to David Cameron’s Tories.Some believe the two were linked — but surely that’s just a conspiracy theory.What is absolutely clear to those who care about the issue is Starmer’s readiness to use his power to curb Press freedom.As citizens of totalitarian regimes rapidly learn to their cost, without a free Press there is no such thing as free speech.IT’S win-win for the Sussexes and losses all round for the House of Windsor.Meghan’s first kiss-and-tell will be a bestseller, with all the gossip on Randy Andy and those secret royal scandals.Harry’s right-on charities will be milked for millions.Once our revered Queen has departed, the monarchy will dwindle to a sideshow on the US celebrity circuit.Charles is too old to compete and William is too dull, despite Kate’s best efforts.Hero Harry will emerge as victor in this grotesque civil war. I predict he will live to regret it. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: debenhams uk store closures latest
story: Read on to find out which branches are set to close, and why.Debenhams is shutting  of its stores this month, as it continues its massive programme of shop closures.At the end of , it was revealed that Debenhams was set to close  of its stores.But  stores have been confirmed to shut in the next three weeks, including Altrincham, Wolverhampton, Ashford and Wimbledon.Heres the full list of closures announced so far:Its believed to be a combination of increasing rents, business rates and a rise in online shopping.Richard Lim of Retail Economics, told the BBC in October  that Debenhams is operating in the part of the market under the most intense amount of pressure.He said: Put simply, department stores are incredibly expensive to run.The combination of too much space, inflexible leases and spiralling operating costs are set against a backdrop an accelerating behavioural sht towards online and experiences.This is eroding their profitability and changes in the business need to occur at a pacethey are to survive.Speaking at the time, Debenhams executive chairman Terry Duddy said: Debenhams has a clear strategy and a bright future, but in order for the business to prosper, we need to restructure the groups store portfolio and its balance sheet, which are not appropriate for todays much changed retail environment.Our priority is to save as many stores and as many jobs as we can, while making the business fit for the future.The retailer, which employs , staff, is now in the hand of lenders as part of this process.They took control of the struggling retailer which wiped out the investments of shareholders, including Sports Direct billionaire Mike Ashley.It would have seen Debenhams lenders agree to write off £million of its £million debts, which the retailer said was not sufficient.Instead, it has chosen to implement a pre-pack administrationThis is an insolvency process for a business to sell its assets before appointing administrations.It is a powerful way of selling on a business to a third part of buyer.The deal doesnt mean that Debenhams will disappear from the high street but some stores will still close.Customers are still able to spend their gt cards title: labours ten point plan end
story: NewsLabours ten-point plan to end anti-semitism in race challenge for new LeaderLabour leaders from the Jewish community in the UK have called for every leader candidate to sign a ten-point pledge to rid the party of vile racismShareCommentsByChris McLaughlin:,  JAN NewsSir Keir and Baroness Lawrence call for MPs to sign pledge against racism " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Anti-semitism has today been thrust to the very heart of the Labour leadership contest with a challenge for all contenders to solve the problem fast.Leaders from the Jewish community have called on every candidate to sign a ten-point pledge to rid the party of vile racism.The move came after Keir Starmer vowed to stamp out anti-semitismhe ­succeeds Jeremy Corbyn .At his campaign launch ­yesterday in Manchester – ­attended by Baroness Doreen Lawrence – he said Labour had not done enough to tackle the issue which had dogged Mr Corbyn. And he vowed: “What I would do is lead from the top and say it’s my responsibility to deal with it. I wouldn’t say it’s for ­somebody . I want the files. I want the numbers on my desk.”  Labour’s General Election campaign was derailed when Chief Rabbi Ephraim Mirvis said Mr Corbyn was unfit for high office because of anti-Semitism and that a victory for Labour would put the “very soul of our nation” at stake.In its statement today, the Board of Deputies of British Jews calls on all ­contenders to sign up to its ten-point plan. It includes settling all outstanding anti-Semitism cases by a fixed deadline. Mr Corbyn’s aides have been ­accused of interfering in cases against members facing claims of anti-Semitism.  The Deputies say the new leader must ensure the ­internal disciplinary process is “independent”. They also call for awareness ­programmes. Prosecutors are considering charges against five people in the party over anti-Semitism. The issue re-emerged ahead of the close of nominations for the leader and deputy leader tomorrow.

title: new black labour mps say
story: NewsNew black Labour MPs say they need name tags as people keep getting them mixed upAbena Oppong-Asare and Florence Eshalomi say they have both already been called the wrong name and mistaken for other politicians since they joined the Houses of Commons in the December electionShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsFlorence Eshalomi has been confused for other black MPs " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTwo newly-elected black Labour MPs have joked that they need name tags after sharing their experiences of being taken for someone . Abena Oppong-Asare and Florence Eshalomi both won their seats in December and have spoken out about attitudes in Parliament. Oppong-Asare, who is MP for Erith and Thamesmead, says she was also handed a bag by a Tory MP to look after because he thought she was someone .  She was also confused with other black women in the Commons. In a Twitter thread she explained: The other day I was outside the @HouseofCommons chamber talking to @DrRosena [Rosena Allin-Khan] and one of the Tory MPs walked straight to me to put his bag in my hands asking me to look after it #ThisIsWhyRepresentationMattersShe said: In my first week someone came up to me confusing me with another black MP. I said no I’m the other black sista from Erith and Thamesmead Labour . He raised he eyebrows and said wow there more of you. Adding: Last week another MP from another party came over to chat to me about a convo we had before Xmas. I realised a few mins in she got me confused with another #BlackSistaShe concluded: Iaposm thinking I might need to write my name on my forehead as I think some people are really struggling to tell the dference. Once Ms Oppong-Asare started posting her experiences fellow newbie Florence Eshalomi joined in the discussion. She tweeted: Girl I also got confused for another black sista MP as we were coming out of the voting lobby...... but I have to admit it was by a fellow Labour MP. Guess we all need to wear massive name tags right.  Their tweets prompted an outpouring of support. Leadership candidate Jess Phillips remarked: Abena you are already making your mark in Parliament as a brilliant force. This experience speaks to so much that is wrong with our parliament and our institutions. You should find the Tory who did it next week and ask them to hold your bag and throw your coat in too! But Rayner faced a backlash for her response to Florence Eshalomi. She commented: “Me and Jess Phillips often have the same problem because we both have an accent despite them being totally dferent.” Some users accused her of comparing their experiences with her experience of being mistaken for other MPs with a strong regional accent. She later deleted the message, saying her remark y had been poorly judged, adding: “As I would in no way compare that to my colleagues who are mistaken due to the colour of their skin.”  It comes as both Clive Lewis and Dawn Butler, who do not yet have the numbers they need to get on the leadership and deputy leadership ballots, have suggested that the Parliamentary Labour Party has an issue with racism. Butler, who has been an MP since  has previously spoken of being mistaken for a cleaner in parliament.

title: richard burgon id build campaigning
story: NewsopinionRichard Burgon: Id build a campaigning Labour Party rooted in every communityWhen I joined the Labour Party back in the mid-s, I admired how John Prescott used the Deputy Leadership as a campaigning roleShareCommentsByRichard Burgon:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsopinionRichard Burgon is a close ally of Jeremy Corbyn " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIn losing the general election Labour let down the communities that need us most. Our every waking moment now needs to be focused on making sure that we win next time. There are no quick fixes. But the first decision we must get right is choosing Labour’s new leadership. When I joined the Labour Party back in the mid-s, I admired how John Prescott used the Deputy Leadership as a campaigning role. I am standing for that same position.  If elected, I’ll be a campaigning Deputy Leader. There will be important parliamentary battles ahead to try to limit the damage of Boris Johnson’s push for Thatcherism .. But as Deputy Leader I mainly want to be out across the country building a Labour Party rooted in every community. We need to show those communities, whose trust we’ve lost, that we’re on their side. We do that by standing side by side with our communities in whatever local battles they face. Be that with the parents forced to fund raise for basic school supplies, women fighting the closure of domestic violence shelters or young fast-food workers demanding fair pay.  Any road back to power for Labour also means reconnecting with those Leave-supporting areas where we lost over  seats. I represent a strongly Leave seat. As Deputy Leader, I will use that experience to chair a Special Commission into how we rebuild in those areas. When it comes to policies, we need to be careful not to throw the baby out with the bathwater. Our last two manestos offer real solutions to the problems our communities face. I don’t believe for a minute that we lost because we offered a £ per hour living wage, promised to build , council houses per year or to scrap tuition fees.  Policies like our Green Industrial Revolution can be part of how we reconnect, especially in areas hit first by Thatcherite deindustrialisation and then by a decade of Tory austerity.  But let’s be honest. Good policies aren’t enoughthey are not being listened to. As Deputy Leader I would overhaul our messaging so it focused around  key popular policies. Our policies must both offer hope of a better country and be easily explainable on the doorstep.

story: NewsTory MP says poor people are fattest and need to be taught to eat healthilySir Desmond Swayne said families on benefits who are forced to turn to foodbanks should learn to do food shopping “more cost effectively”ShareCommentsByAdam Aspinall:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsSir Desmond Swayne said families on benefits who are forced to turn to foodbanks should learn to do food shopping “more cost effectively” " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Tory MP has been blasted for saying poor people are the “fattest” and need to be taught how to shop more healthily. Sir Desmond Swayne said families on benefits who are forced to turn to foodbanks should learn to do food shopping “more cost effectively”. Writing in a local newspaper he argued foodbanks are an “important contribution” to the welfare system. But checks should be made to see how families “actually spend” their benefits, the MP for New Forest West, in Hampshire added. The former aide to ex-PM David Cameron said: “The shocking statistic is one in five of our children is obese by the time they leave primary school and this disproportionately affects those children in the lowest household incomes. To put it bluntly : the poorest are amongst the fattest. “The conclusion I draw is their families need, in addition to welfare payments, help with how to shop more cost effectively and healthily.”
