story: NewsBrit backpackers left clinging to le as car flipped onto roof in Australian outbackBest friends Robyn Jago, , and Elyse O’Donnell, from Merseyside, are recovering from their horror injuries after the terrying car crash while on their dream tripShareCommentsByCharlotte Hadfield:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsBest friends Robyn Jago and Elyse O’Donnell " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTwo backpackers were left clinging to le after their car lost control and flipped onto its roof in a remote spot in the middle of the Australian outback. Best friends Robyn Jago, , and Elyse O’Donnell, from Merseyside, have described their terrying experience while on a dream trip. Their adventure took a devastating turn when a tyre on the car they were travelling in burst, causing it to lose control and veer off in the wrong direction, the Liverpool Echo reports. Elyse, who was driving the car at the time, tried to regain control but it soon hit a dip at the side of the road causing it to flip onto its roof and hit a nearby tree, which smashed straight through the windscreen. They escaped the car with severe injuries, including broken backs, and the emergency services were four hours away. Robyn from Halewood, and Elyse, from Stockbridge Village, travelled over to Perth together from Thailand, back in February . After securing jobs on a farm, the pair spent the following year working “in the middle of nowhere” in Broome and Hallscreek, in order to save up enough money to travel up the East coast. But on September , their trip took a devastating turn. Robyn said she first realised that something was wrong, when she smelt “burning rubber” coming from the tyres - but it was already too late. Ironically, Australian police told Robynshe had not had removed her seat-belt she would have been impaled by the tree.  Robyn told the Echo: “I woke up and I was on my hands and knees scrunched up in a ball. I donapost remember being in the air flipping. I just remember seeing a tiny glimpse out of the window which I knew wasnapost the road. I was trying to understand what had happened when I saw a light switch on the floor next to me and thataposs when I realised that it was actually the roof of the car and that we were upside down. Robyn and Elyse were in the car with two other women, who they had met the month before, but who have asked not to be named.  Seconds before the accident, Robyn had unfastened her seat belt in order to change position in the tightly packed car, meaning she took the full force of the crash. Robyn said: Your senses slowly start coming back to you and I heard screaming and Elyseaposs voice. “She had managed to get out of the car by this point withand they were stood on the side of the road. When I looked to my right I sawcovered in blood, I thought she was dead. She had blood all over her face and wounds where the tree had scraped her. I screamed.” Robyn said: “Elyse could hear a hissing noise coming from the car so she thought it was going to blow. “She was shouting ‘you need to get out of the car.”  By this point, Robyn said she knew she had broken her back but they had no other option but to get out of the car. She said: “I couldn’t get out of the side I was on so we had to get out of the other side but there was a branch coming through the window. “Elyse andhad to pull us both out in the end.” Robyn suffered from a bleed on the brain during the crash and was left with a broken back and a burst finger. Elyse broke her back and neck in five dferent places.  One of the other two women who was travelling in the car at the time of the crash sustained a total of  serious injuries including a wound to the head, while the other was left with black eye and a torn ligament to the shoulder. Robyn said: “I never take my seatbelt off, I literally just took it off for a minute to get comfortable. “But the police told me afterwards thatI had had my seat belt on there was a good chance I would have been impaled by the tree and would probably have been dead by now.” After managing to escape from the vehicle, the girls stood “shaking” as they tried to work out what to do next. Robyn said the crash took place literally in the middle of nowhere” and was a three and a half hour drive away from the nearest hospital. However, thanks to a lorry driver who was driving past shortly after the accident, the girls managed to get to the roadside to call for help. Robyn said: “We were far away from the road because of where the car landed butheard a lorry going past so she bombed it up to the side of the road.  She told him aposweaposve just been in a car crash’ and he grabbed his first aid kit, he was lovely.” There was a mining site not too far away so he called there and said ‘have you got first aiders to help in any way they can. Robyn said it took a total of four hours for an ambulance and police to arrive at the scene of the crash. The girls were then taken to the nearest clinic,  minutes away, to be assessed before Robyn was taken with one of the other women, by air ambulance to Broome Hospital. While Elyse and her other friend who was involved in the crash, were taken to Kunnuara Hospital the following day. Robyn said: “The first person Elyse told was her mum. She panicked at first because all Elyse did was cry down the phone but then once she told her everyone’s alive and she went really calm and calmed Elyse right down. “Elyse told my sister for me because I lost my phone in the crash. It was so surreal it honestly still doesn’t feel like it happened to us.”  Robyn spent the following eight days after the accident being treated in hospital before she was discharged over the course of a week, while Elyse spent the following nine days in hospital. Due to the severity of both of their injuries, they were fitted with neck braces and had to attend hospital appointments several times a week for the following three months. Robyn said: We were both in absolute agony. After we were discharged from hospital we spent the next three months mostly indoors at our friendaposs house. I had to go back to the hospital for constant checks. I was put on medication for my brain haemorrhage and memory games and brain training. We could walk but we spent a lot of time lying down because of the pain. We were tired all the time, we just had no energy. Since the accident, Robyn and Elyse have made a good progress with their injuries and had their back braces removed in December. Despite being able to walk now unsupported, Robyn said they are both unable toto work until at least March and suffer from a lot of pain which makes it a nightmare to sleep at night. Robyn said the psychological pain of the accident, has also been unbearable with both Elyse and herself regularly suffering from flash backs and night terrors. But due to the high cost of receiving physiotherapy for their injuries and counselling, the girls have been unable to get the help they desperately need. Robyn said: Itaposs taken a toll on our mental health. Iaposve had depression and anxiety before but itaposs been a whole new level since the accident. Weaposve had to sit indoors for three months watching our savings disappear while we recover. Weaposve both struggled to sleep since. We have sleep paralysis and suffer from nightly flashbacks. She added: Weaposre so scared of travelling in cars now. Weaposll be in a taxi and itaposll change lanes and we both get so nervous. Weaposre just very nervous about everything little thing. The doctor has told us weaposre not allowed to go back to work until March.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA boy who was kicked out of school at the age of just five is still not allowed tofour months later. Last September, just two days into the new school year , Rudi Barnes was permanently excluded from St Malachyaposs RC Primary in Miles Platting, Manchester. Headteacher Mrs Janine Parker took the decision after an incident in which he kicked and punched teaching staff, tipped over chairs and a table, and pulled displays off a wall. It was the culmination of a pattern of violent behaviour that began in nursery when he was just three. He hasnapost had another day in school since his exclusion, the Manchester Evening News reports. The week before Christmas, little Rudi was writing out cards for all his classmates. His parents Claire Scae and Carl Barnes had to take them in to school for him, but they fear Rudi is already being left behind. He went to a friendaposs birthday party and this kid said aposnobody remembers you in school apos, said Claire, . He got really upset, itaposs heartbreaking. While the parents understand why the school made the drastic decision, they are distraught and believe more should have been done to keep him in school and get him the help he clearly needs. The couple say they have no idea where Rudiaposs behaviour comes from and that it doesnapost happen at home.  Certainly, Rudiaposs exclusion is unusual. There were just  children permanently excluded aged five across the country in -, according to the Department for Education. In Manchester, only thirteen pupils in total were permanently excluded from state-funded primary schools. The advice to headteachers is that it should be an absolute last resort. However,  as the M.E.N has reported previously  , soaring rates of exclusions has been a serious problem in Manchester schools in recent years. A government review, led by former childrenaposs minister Edward Timpson and published last year, pointed to an array of negative outcomes for children who are excluded including a reduced likelihood of achieving good GCSEs, a higher chance of ending up unemployed and a higher chance of being either the victim, or perpetrator of a crime. In November , Manchester Council responded by launching a new aposInclusion Strategyapos that was designed to tackle exclusion rates. But the sad story of how Rudi Barnes came to be kicked out of school at such a young age, and his parentsapos ongoing battle to make sure he gets an education, highlights how this continues to be a challenging problem.Many of those tasked with preventing exclusions, from school staff to mental health services, are struggling with a rapidly increasing workload and dwindling budgets after a decade of government funding cuts. Four months after his permanent exclusion, Rudi still hasnapost had another day at school or been assessed by a mental health professional, despite being referred to Child and Adolescent Mental Health Servicesat least nine times, the M.E.N understands. By law, the local authority must make arrangements for a childaposs full time education from the sixth day of exclusion onwards. Rudi has been offered alternative provision at Bridgelea, a Pupil Referral Unit , for permanently excluded children but it has left the parents in a quandry. There used to be a Bridgelea site in Gorton, near to their home in Miles Platting, but that closed in . The main PRU site is in Withington, almost six miles away and several bus journeys away for Claire and Carl who do not have a car and are reliant on state benefits. Carl, , is a full-time carer to partner Claire who has diabetes, and is also responsible for getting Rudiaposs nine-year-old brother and two-year-old sister to school every day. The family borrowed a car to take Rudi for a day visit to Bridgelea and after meeting the headteacher, they believe the school can provide the support he needs. But the couple feel it is simply aposimpossibleapos for Carl to get the other children to school and also take Rudi to Bridgelea.  Carl and Claire were hoping Rudi could get funding from the council for transport from home to school but so far none has materialised. Manchester Council says Rudi has been provided with a bus pass for free travel and ultimately, there is no excuse for him not to be at Bridgelea. The authority has now threatened to prosecute Carl and Claire for failing to send their child to school, although it has agreed to pause proceedings after the M.E.N requested a comment about the case. If convicted, the couple face a fine or even a prison sentence. They said they will take me to court, said Carl. Fine,thataposs what it takes to explain it all, we will go to court. It seems extreme that Rudiaposs future should now be decided in a criminal court room. Carl and Claire struggle to understand how it got to this point. Speaking at the familyaposs neatly-kept home last week, the couple showed the M.E.N a pile of paper documents relating to Rudiaposs problems at school. It has already been a long and intimidating process. Rudiaposs violent behaviour began just months after he first started in nursery at St Malachyaposs in September . As might be expected of such a young child, many of the incidents were petulant in nature. They offered him a pear, and he doesnapost like pears, said Carl. So he threw it at the teacher and cut her lip. He was excluded from reception for that. Staff tried to handle Rudiaposs outbursts by taking him out of the room, but by reception, his behaviour was escalating. They said he was just getting more angry, said Carl They did get a psychologist in, a behaviour specialist. But they only came one day and didnapost see anything. The teacher told us theyaposre trained in holding techniques but they donapost like using it. If theyaposd have held him until he calmed down, then he gives hugs and kisses out to the teachers. If theyaposd held him, he wouldnapost have got excluded, or he would have got the help earlier on.  In response to Claire and Carlaposs claims, a spokesperson for the Diocese of Salford, the organisation that runs St Malchyaposs said: It would not be appropriate to comment on the inidual circumstances of any one pupil . At St Malachyaposs all decisions are taken in the best interest of our school community. However, it is understood the schoolaposs position is that only aposselectedapos, more senior staff are trained in holding techniques and that other de-escalation techniques were used with Rudi following advice from an external behaviour consultant. Often, Rudi doesnapost appear to even remember what has happened after a violent episode at school and will be hugging the same teachers he was hitting only minutes earlier. Claire and Carl describe their son as a aposlovingapos little boy who likes giving out hugs so much he even embraces the staff at his local ASDA.  Rudi has both younger and older siblings and doesnapost seem to suffer the same rage blackouts with them or his parents.  I said to one of the teachers aposis it really that bad apos said Claire.   So she showed me a video of it on the iPad and I couldnapost believe it. I thought aposis that really Rudi apos thataposs not my son. He was in a rage, his face looked dferent and everything I thought aposoh my godapos. I was heartbroken.   Itaposs like he sees red and doesnapost know what heaposs doing, but I donapost know what triggers it off.   This is what we want to find out - weaposve been begging for help. Over the past eighteen months, Rudiaposs parents, his GP and staff at St Malachyaposs have all referred him to Child and Adolescent Mental Health Serviceson several occasions. But CAMHS repeatedly refused to see Rudi on the basis he did not aposfit the criteriaapos. Carl and Claire say they were told in person they would have to wait until he was six before he would be seen. That appears to be true as CAMHS offered an appointment three days after Rudi turned six in December. But while they are happy to finally see a step forward, Carl and Claire fear it will still be a y process before Rudi gets the help he needs. And they believeRudi had been seen earlier, he might not have ended up being permanently excluded in the first place.  Heaposs heartbroken he canapost go to school, but itaposs just aposhard luck, nobodyaposs going to even look at you yetapos, said Claire. We shouldnapost be in this predicament, it should all be in place before the child is permanently excluded. He should have been sent to the PRU while he was at school. Weaposve looked into finding him another one nearer us but there isnapost one. I went in [to CAMHS] crying saying aposplease help me, what have I got to do apos, they said heaposs got to be six. Meanwhile, with Rudi now having been out of school for more than four months, the effects are starting to show. His preference is to be at St Malachyaposs and his absence is made all the more painful as he often accompanies his dad when dropping off and picking up his older brother. Mum Claire says Rudi now often refuses to eat or hides food around the house at meal times. The teacher hugged him the other day and said aposRudi youaposve lost weightapos, said Claire. Itaposs shocking. At dinner, he was crying, aposIaposm not eating it, Iaposm not eating itapos. He goes to pick his brother up and heaposs crying saying aposwhy canapost I go to school apos Heaposs only a baby - he doesnapost know whataposs happened. He says aposIaposm missing my friendsapos. Heaposs missing out on a lot. Claire and Carl are aware that some people might write them off as bad parents because of Rudiaposs predicament. But they say they couldnapost be trying any harder to do whataposs best for him and get him back in school. We just feel like weaposre hitting our heads off a wall, said Claire. The doctor said, aposyouaposve hit a brick wall, thereaposs no help out there for that age groupapos.  Imagine we were those parents who donapost caretheir kids go to school  Our kids donapost get a day off. We make sure they get up in the morning, theyaposre not even late.  It seems like itaposs all down to money though, nobody wants to help you, you get told aposphone this person, phone that personapos, weaposve phoned that many people weaposre going round in circles. Manchester Council funds aposhome to schoolapos transport services via the Travel Co-Ordination Unit. It is a complicated process that usually involves a child already having a statement of Special Educational Needsor Education, Health and Careplan. Rudi has neither because he has yet to be assessed by a professional. But evenhe does get an SEN statement, his parents may struggle to get travel support getting him to school. In its - budget, the council said there are aposexisting budget pressuresapos totalling £.million aposrelating to Special Education Needs and Disabilityhome to school transport, leaving care accommodation and adoption allowances. As a result, the council intends to save £, from its Travel Co-Ordination budget between -. However, the M.E.N understands efforts are now being made to try and resolve the situation with Rudiaposs travel arrangements. He is also due to have his first appointment with the CAMHS service in the next few days. But Claire and Carl still have a long way to go with getting Rudi back in full-time education and receiving the help he needs. There must be other kids going through this, said Carl. I think it should be highlighted that no matter what age you are,you need help, you need help. Not just my kids, all the other kids out there. In  , there were  permanent exclusions from Manchester schools, a decrease of  compared with the year before. This included  in secondary school and  in primary. But the details of Rudiaposs case suggests there is still work to do.

The young women - many of which are Muslim - are undergoing aposvirginity repairapos operations to aposensureapos they are apospureapos for their wedding night. Some private clinics charge up to £, for the invasive procedure - called hymenoplasty - and are luring patients with with advertisements that promise the surgery can aposrestore your innocenceapos and are apos per cent safeapos.An investigation by the Sunday Times found there to be at least  clinics offering the service privately, mostly in London.Campaigners have accused the clinics of capitalising on the fears of patients, the majority of which are young Muslim women from Middle Eastern and Asian families under pressure to be aposuntouchedapos when they marry. Extramarital sex, or zina, is forbidden by the Koran. Critics have slammed doctors for reinforcing the the belief that the hymen is a apossealapos that breaks during sex - when in fact only half of women bleed when they lose their virginity. One London schoolgirl saved up £, to have the surgery a few days before her th birthday after finding out she was being forced to marry a much older man. She said: I had a secret boyfriend and we were happy, but I knew my parnts would never let me marry him. She got the surgery over fears her brother would attack her aposfor bringing shame on the familyaposher mother-in-law did not see blood on the sheets following the wedding night as expected. She used her birthday money to cover the procedures at a London clinic, saying it was painful and left her with a nasty infection. She said three months later when she bled on her wedding night she was relieved she didnapost bring shame on her family, adding: My family were happy and so were his. One clinic, Regency International, which comes top of Google searches for the procedures, claims on its website that a hymenoplasty is often being performed for psychological healing.The clinic claimsa woman has suffered rape or sexual abuse, it is very likely that her Hymen will have been torn. The procedure may not only offer the physical restoration she seeks but may also supply some psychological comfort and healing as well. Charities believe hundreds of patients are undergoing the procedure in the UK every year. The operation, also known as hymen repair, involves constructing a layer of skin at the entrance to the vagina that can tear when a woman first has sexual intercourse. It takes less than an hour and is performed under local anaesthetic.  Mohammad Masood, director of MAS Gynaecology, said requests for the procedure at his Harley Street clinic had risen four-fold since . He said his patients typically found him online and were almost exclusively Muslim but other patients were from the Roma community. He said about a third of his patients travel to the UK, mainly from Iran and Turkey, where the proecdure is available but considered a taboo. He denies claims that surgeons are cashing in on womenaposs fears and instead says he feels he has saved lives, adding: It is a very sad situation. Halaleh Taheri, founder of the Middle Eastern Women and Society Organisation, based in Finsbury Park, north London, said she had dealt with several cases of young women who had grown up in the UK and were sexually active but then forced into marriage.

story: NewsCouple buys dump house from council for £ and turn it into £, homeEXCLUSIVE: Debbie and Ste Hodges hard work paid off as their blood and guts has transformed their Liverpool home into a valuable asset for just £,ShareCommentsByEmily Hall:,  JAN NewsDebbie and Ste Hodge and their home on Garrick Street in Liverpool which they bought for just £ " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDelighted Debbie and Ste Hodge are finally quids in after buying a house for a pound and turning it into a £, asset. They put “blood, sweat and tears” into the two-bed dump, bought under a council regeneration scheme. Debbie and Ste were shaken when they first stepped through the door – armed with a £, schedule of works from Liverpool City Council to bring it up to scratch. The th century terraced house had been hit by fire and had crumbling walls, broken bricks and burnt joists. But the couple worked -, did most of the renovations themselves and in  months transformed it into a cosy home for just £,. After enjoying their first Christmas in the double-fronted home in the city’s Wavertree district, the pair have been buoyed by a valuation of £,. Debbie, , says: “We never want to move because we have put so much of ourselves into this house. People thought we were nuts. “We’ve crawled on the floors, we built the floors… it’s a gamble we took and we love it. Our blood and guts have gone into it. If they’d give us next door, we’d do it again!” Recalling the first time she saw the property, Debbie says: “It was just a shell. All the joists were burnt. It was terrible. “Honestly, it was just stacks and stacks of bricks. There was nothing. My family were saying to me, ‘You’re mad’.”  Every floor had to be replaced, chimneys were removed, the sinking kitchen was underpinned, all fittings were ripped out and the windows were upgraded. Debbie and Ste, , used their savings and took a small loan to complete the work – and it was hard graft. We were there until midnight with torches. We went seven days a week, we didn’t miss a day,” Debbie says. She scoured local ads for bargains and bagged a £, kitchen for a tenth of the price and a £, bathroom suite for £,. They also picked up a slightly damaged £, front door for £.  And, slowly but surely, the place came together. Now it is a shining example of how Liverpool is breathing new le into former slums. The council unveiled its Homes For A Pound scheme in . A year later, bosses vowed that , empty houses would be brought back into use. story: NewsQueen spotted with hearing aid for first time ahead of Harry and Meghan showdown talksThe Queen has been seen wearing a hearing aid in public at Sandringham for what is believed the first time as she prepares for royal talks about Harry and Meghans future roles on MondayShareCommentsByLucy Skoulding:,  JAN NewsThe Queen has been seen wearing a hearing aid in public for the first time ahead of talks about Harry and Meghans future roles " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The Queen has been spotted in public wearing a hearing aid for what is believed to be the first time ahead of crunch talks about Harry and Meghanaposs future roles. At , Queen Elizabeth II was snapped with a brown and red device in her ear following a church service in Sandringham before talks with senior royals and the Duke of Sussex on Monday. This moment comes five years after her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, was seen wearing discreet behind-the-ear hearing aids for the first time in October , also aged . However the Queen appeared to be wearing in-the-canal hearing aids, which the NHS England website states arenapost usually powerful enough for people with severe hearing loss. Apparently theyaposre only helpfulthe wearer has some hearing left but needs assistance hearing everyday noises like doorbells, speech and phones, as itaposs the start of their hearing failing. The Queen arrived at her private Norfolk estate in her camel coat and hat amid the Harry and Meghan crisis, and was spotted after a morning service at St Mary Magdalene Church. Tomorrow the family will get together to discuss the next steps for the Duke and Duchess of Sussex after their announcement that they plan to step down as senior royals, become financially independent and split their time between the UK and North America. Meanwhile, Meghan headed to Canada on an £ budget flight to avoid detection.Itaposs a decision that has apparently left the Queen and other senior royals feeling hurt. On Thursday the Queen, Charles and William gave orders for their households to work together with the Sussexes to find a workable solution to their desire to change their royal lives but still support the Queen.  The family will gather on Monday at Sandringham to talk things through, attended by Her Majesty, the Prince of Wales, the Duke of Cambridge and the Duke of Sussex, said a royal source. Following a series of meetings and consultations across the last few days, there are a range of possibilities for the family to review which take into account the thinking the Sussexes outlined earlier in the week.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA contestant on television’s ­gruelling SAS show today tells how she owes her le to her little sister – who is competing alongside her. Bethany Robinson, , suffers from bipolar disorder and planned to throw herself in front of a train as she battled through a “dark depression”. It was only when her sister Elouise Gregor, , introduced her to weightlting and CrossFit exercise that Bethany’s condition eased. It proved to be the making of her – literally saving her le. Bethany says: “If Elouise hadn’t have helped me, I wouldnapost be here today.” Now they are the first sisters to take part in SAS: Who Dares Wins – the Channel  show that sees recruits go through brutal special forces training. Bethany, an art teacher from Cornwall, says: “I was in a black hole and didn’t know how to get out. I definitely would have killed myself. “My sister rang my mum the day I’d planned to do it and my mum called the police, who came and got me. “I don’t remember the two months after that because I was in such a deep depression. Elouise hatched a plan to help me. She set up a home gym and encouraged me to start exercising. I began feeling better straight away – it set me on the road to recovery.” Bethany had put on weight during her depression and reached  stone. But after working out, she lost six stone in a year. She has since lost a further stone. The sisters compete in CrossFit and Olympic power-lting and have dozens of podium finishes between them.  Elouise, a solicitor, says: “It was horric seeing Beth being so self-destructive and unhappy. I would have done anything to help her. “She pushed me away, but the gym was the place we reconnected. We became best friends again.” Bethany’s issues began after she left an abusive relationship aged . She was diagnosed with bipolar disorder after two particularly bad episodes. She explains: “I was in the darkest depression, but I had lots of energy because I was coming off of a manic period and had been out partying.  “My mind was telling me there was no way out and nothing was ever going to get better. All I could think about was killing myself. It was totally irrational. “It happened twice. The first time, I planned to throw myself under a train. I was determined to do it. Luckily the train station was closed and my sister rang my mum, who called the police. “The second time, I had all these thoughts about killing myself. I banged my head against a wall, because I thoughtI could knock myself out, the thoughts would stop. I got help after those two episodes – I don’t think I’d have survived a third.”  Bethany began counselling and was put on medication in mid-. But by the end of the year, doctors told her it wasn’t working. That’s when Elouise stepped in and encouraged Bethany – who had been sporty in her youth – to start working out. They lted weights in their home gym and Bethany found she was good at it. She says: “I got back into fitness by deadlting – I could lt kg, which is a huge amount for a woman. It made me fall in love with the sport and I started going to CrossFit six times a week with Elouise. I felt the exercise helping straight away. It made me confident. Suddenly I was good at something. “I started to feel so much better about myself. It really brought me closer to my sister. We became best friends again. We encourage each other.”  Exercising was so helpful to Bethany’s mental health that she now no longer has bipolar episodes. She says: “Since I found fitness, my mental health issues have been under control. My mood still fluctuates, but not dramatically. It is now within the normal range. I found that with good sleep, nutrition and exercise, I can control my bipolar. It’s been amazing, I never looked back.” Spurred on by her recovery and her love of fitness, Bethany applied to go on the TV show – and Elouise followed suit. They were invited to a fitness test and got told off for cheering each other on! The show sees contestants pushed to the limits, physically and mentally.  But the sisters – who feature in tonight’s episode – loved every minute. Bethany says: “We communicate without even having to speak, so it was a great support being there together. “With everything I’ve been through, taking part in SAS has actually been a lot of fun. It made me deal with a lot of things, which is a positive. It proved to me I’m stronger than I think I am. “It helped me overcome moments of doubt. It pulls you apart and puts you back together. I wanted to prove that, after my mental health struggles with bipolar disorder, I’m OK now. “I can not only cope with the stresses of competing in a sport and everyday le, but I can take on one of the most stressful and challenging courses and come out just as mentally strong as before. “Having bipolar disorder no longer holds me back.”

title: shoppers being taken fools stores
story: NewsShoppers being taken for fools with stores passing off real fur as fakeEXCLUSIVE: Investigators bought  fur-trimmed items from markets and stores in Durham, Leeds, London, Newcastle, Stratford-upon-Avon and York, as well as online - All the items were found to contain real animal fur, including a pair of children’s shoes and a baby’s hatShareCommentsByNada FarhoudEnvironment editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsA YouGov poll found nearly half of shoppers rely on the feel and price of fur to decideit is real" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailShopping centres and markets are awash with real fur clothes masquerading as fake, made from the pelts of foxes, rabbits and raccoon dogs, a Mirror probe can reveal. Fur-trimmed jackets, shoes, hats and gloves were found with labels either making no mention of their origins or claiming they are synthetic. Investigators bought  fur-trimmed items ranging from £ to £ from markets and stores in Durham, Leeds, London, Newcastle, Stratford-upon-Avon and York, as well as online. All the items were found to contain real animal fur, including a pair of children’s shoes and a baby’s hat. Claire Bass, director of animal rights organisation Humane Society International UK, said: Buyers beware: the plethora of real fur items we found being sold as faux shows avoiding animal fur continues to be a minefield for shoppers. There’s a misconception thata garment is cheap, it is faux fur.” A £. pair of  shoes from web-site Ego were labelled as “black faux fur” but were found to be fox. A £ pair of kids’ plimsolls from EverythingPounds labelled “faux fur trim” were found to contain rabbit. A £ pair of “faux fur” pink diamante trainers from online fashion store Cucu were found to contain rabbit. A Walthamstow Market trader in East London said the pom-pom on a £ baby’s hat was “fake”. He told investigators: “I don’t have real fur as it’s too expensive.” But tests showed otherwise.  A street vendor in Leeds sold us a £ hat, saying: “It’s not animal fur. It would be more expensive. But the pom-pom was found to be raccoon dog fur. A vendor at Stratford Indoor Market, in east London, said it was “not possible to get a pair of real fur gloves for £”, unaware those he sold had a rabbit trim. A YouGov poll found nearly half of shoppers rely on the feel and price of fur to decideit is real. Many still believe real fur is expensive.  But retailers can bulk-buy rabbit fur trim from online wholesalers for as little as £ a metre. Fur farming was banned in the UK in , with the last farm closing in . But it is still legal to import fur, with millions of pounds’ worth flooding in. Clare Bass said: “In most cases, we don’t believe the vendors are deliberately misleading customers. They genuinely believe what they’re selling is faux fur.  Le’s cheap on a fur farm and that misery is reflected in the rock-bottom price.” Cucu Fashion removed the trainers from its site to investigate. It said: “We work with suppliers from the UK and Europe and were advised they don’t use real fur.We’re disappointed they’ve breached our high standards.” Ego fashion said: “Heel Sassy has been taken off the site to be investigated.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailStrong gales of up to mph are set to sweep across parts of the UK on Monday. The Met Office has warned coastal routes and communities could be particularly affected by Storm Brendan as large waves batter seafronts. Yellow weather warnings are in place for Northern Ireland, much of the western half of the UK and the north east of Scotland from pm on Monday to midnight. Met Office meteorologist Frank Saunders said the UK and Ireland will turn increasingly windy throughout Monday as the storm, named by Irish forecaster Met Éireann, sweeps in. He said: Itaposs going to be windy across the western half of the UK, with gusts reaching -mph along Irish Sea coastlines, the west of Scotland and perhaps some English Channel coasts - maybe even mph in a few exposed places. Mr Saunders added those in affected areas are advised to take extra care when driving on exposed routes such as bridges or high open roads. He said: As Storm Brendan moves eastwards, strong winds will also develop across eastern parts of the UK, particularly northeast Scotland where there is also a wind warning in place. As well as strong winds, there will be large coastal waves in western areas, so bear this in mind before heading out in these regions.  Looking further ahead to the rest of next week, he said: It looks like itaposs going to stay very unsettled with the potential for further disruptive weather in places. On Saturday, strong winds and heavy rain battered parts of Scotland, causing road closures and rail disruption. The main A road from the English border up to the Edinburgh area was closed to high-sided vehicles for several hours.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailStrong winds could cause travel chaos when Storm Brendan strikes tomorrow, the Met Office has warned as it issued a yellow weather warning. Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and the west of England will be hit by gusts of up mph tomorrow, and these will spread across all of England and Wales on Tuesday. Forecasters say coastal areas are set to be battered as the storm crosses the Irish Sea. It will be accompanied by heavy rain, and is likely to disrupt rail, air and sea travel. The yellow warning comes into effect at am tomorrow and will last until midnight on Tuesday - but unsettled weather will continue through the week. Met Office Chief Meteorologist Frank Saunders said: “The UK and Ireland will turn increasingly windy on Monday, as Storm Brendan approaches, and thereaposll also be some heavy rain. It’s going to be particularly windy across the western half of the UK, with gusts reaching - mph along Irish Sea coastlines, the west of Scotland and perhaps some English Channel coasts - maybe even  mph in a few exposed places. This is likely to cause some disruption to sea, road and air travel. The weather chief continued: As Storm Brendan moves eastwards, strong winds will also develop across eastern parts of the UK, particularly northeast Scotland where there is also a wind warning in place.” “As well as strong winds, there will be large coastal waves in western areas, so bear this in mind before heading out in these regions.”  It is likely that unsettled weather will continue throughout the week, the Met Office says. On Saturday, strong winds and heavy rain battered parts of Scotland, causing road closures and rail disruption. The main A road from the English border up to the Edinburgh area was closed to high-sided vehicles for several hours.

title: vaping tycoons slammed 1p hour
story: NewsVaping tycoons slammed for p-an-hour contract clause to punish workersBrothers Callum and Connor Henderson put the term into the workers contract to shame those leaving without being sering a full notice periodShareByJohn FergusonTfany Lo:,  JAN NewsConnor Henderson now lives a millionaires lestyle " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTwo bosses running a vaping business have been blasted for threatening workers with a shameful pay rate of p per hour. Edinburgh-based tycoons Callum and Connor Henderson put the terms into contracts for staff who leave the company without serving a full notice period. Callun,  and Connor, , have become two of Scotlandaposs most successful businessmen after their VPZ electronic cigarette shop chain expanded across the UK, reports the Daily Record. But their harsh contract terms have been deemed to be a breach of a raft of laws by politicians, unions and lawyers. The Sunday Mail revealed the documents showing the terms that workers could end up receiving just p an hour for time worked and holidays owed. After being confronted, the company claimed the clause had since been removed from their terms of employment. But a source said: This was given to a worker in recent years and was the one they were employed under until leaving the company in recent months. It is disgusting to try to treat people like that and it would never stand up in court. The contract states: In the event of an employee leaving the company without the proper notice period being served, the company will make payment of any outstanding hours worked and outstanding holiday entitlement owed by the company which will be calculated at the rate of pper hour.  Lawyer David Martyn, head of Thompsonsapos employment rights unit, believes the terms wouldnapost comply with other laws to protect workers’ rights. He said: If you don’t have statutory rules governing the way people are paid, you will see this sort of punitive clause appearing more regularly. You can see what it is designed to do – punish people for not working their full notice period. But the reality is thatyou have earned holidays, you are entitled to be paid for those under Working Time Regulations, andyou have done work, then you are entitled to be paid at the very least the National Minimum Wage. A contract cannot drop the rate of pay below the National  Minimum Wage  – it is a piece of legislation that is there to provide a floor. A term like that would seem to me to be void because it would be effectively overwritten by the statutory provisions which would be applied by a court. If you broaden this issue out, this is the concern about Brexit and attempts to deregulate the economy. You are in a situation where some of the basic rights that we rely on to create a fair working relationship are easily removed.  Citizens Advice Scotland’s social justice spokesperson Mhoraig Green said: This story will shock people across Scotland. The idea that workers could effectively be paid p an hour in any circumstance is utterly jaw-dropping. “People not knowing their rights at work is an issue and that leads to some companies taking advantage of their workers.” The meteoric success of VPZ has allowed the Henderson brothers to rake it in and splash out. Callum, , lives in a £.million six-bed Edinburgh mansion – complete with cinema and indoor swimming pool – with -year-old girlfriend Liliana Recinos from El Salvador.  Recinos regularly flaunts her extravagant lestyle on Facebook , with pictures of their sprawling home and luxury holidays. Connor, , lives in a turreted, seven-bed Victorian mansion set in two acres of land near Linlithgow, West Lothian, with his girlfriend Hrafnhildur Matthiasdottir, from Iceland, and their two daughters. The brothers started with a single shop in Edinburgh’s Leith in  but now have  outlets across Britain and  staff. Accounts show the firm turned over £million in  and VPZ is believed to be worth more than £ million.

title: voice mirror prince harry lacks
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Prince Harry lacks dignity of Queen after hot-headed royal exitIn more than  years on the throne, the Queen has shown with impeccable style, dignity and judgement how the “old firm” should be runShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsopinionPrince Harry lacks dignity of Queen after his impulsive exit " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHarry and Meghan got it wrong. Plain and simple. While many sympathise with the Duke and Duchess of Sussex’s desire to step back as senior Royals, the way they chose to do it has provoked justiable shock and outrage. Petulant, hot-headed and impulsive are just some of the barbs aimed at the couple after the bombshell public announcement that they wished to become part-time Royals and live much of the time abroad. Inconsiderate, disloyal and reckless might also be appropriate. In more than  years on the throne, the Queen has shown with impeccable style, dignity and judgement how the “old firm” should be run. The sacrices she and other members of the Royal Family have made have been not only for the monarchy, but for the nation.  That, by the antiquated system of a monarchic state, is their responsibility by birth. And Her Majesty embraced that responsibility with grace, as even republicans admit. Harry and Meghan’s wish to break away might be seen as an understandable cry for modernisation. Their desire to do so has been evident for a long time. But discussing their intentions with friends such as Elton John before the Queen, and going ahead with their announcement without thinking through the full impact on their family or the monarchy, has caused a totally avoidable crisis. That the Queen has had to intervene – calling a Royal showdown at Sandringham tomorrow to deal with the crisis – is a measure of the scale of the embarrassment caused.  She is right to step in and call the wayward couple to heel. Only she has the authority to bang heads together and ensure a smoother route to whatever the future holds. The Wrong Cure  The crisis in our health service starts at the front line, the family doctor. The GP is an absolute cornerstone of the National Health Service, the first stop for all ages from cradle to grave. It is a service that is essential to personal health, and to the economy of the country. With a shortage of at least , GPs, Tory promises of more on the way are not enough. Government action on over-complicated red tape preventing overseas doctors from coming here to ease the gap is long overdue. Rocking On Rod Stewart is a national treasure who just refuses to act his age.

title: where you bury twin begs
story: NewsWhere did you bury my twin  begs woman whose sister was killed by evil fiancéEXCLUSIVE: Denise Murray, of Northern Ireland, demands answers from her sisters killer Johnny Miller but he refuses to talk as he awaits a le sentence for her murderShareCommentsByClaire OBoyle:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN News " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTwins Denise and Charlotte Murray were constant companions – but that didn’t suit control freak Johnny Miller. And everything changed soon after Charlotte fell under his influence at the age of . She moved away from her home town to live with him. And within a year she was dead. Chef Miller, , pretended his fiancée had disappeared but was ­convicted of her murder after a long police investigation. As he awaits a le sentence, he refuses to tell officers how he killed Charlotte or where he disposed of her body. Tonight her twin Denise, , spoke of the family’s agony at not knowing what happened. She said: “We can’t come to terms with it. We can’t move on because we don’t have the end of the story. “We have no grave to visit. We have nowhere to go and say a prayer and leave flowers.” Denise will never forget the beginning of the ordeal that led to discovering her sister’s death. It began with her waking from a restless sleep one night. “I felt like I was being choked and like someone had thrown something in my face,” she said. “I sat there coughing and spluttering in the dark, panicked because I couldn’t breathe. “When I got my breath back I just lay there, frightened, and the nerves of it stayed with me for a few days. I was anxious and emotional and I couldn’t figure out why.  “Nothing like that had ever happened to me before.” Denise believes the night it happened in November  could have been the night Charlotte was killed. Police think her sister was murdered about then. At the trial last October, prosecution lawyers said Miller killed his fiancée in a ­“murderous rage” and that on the morning of her disappearance she had sent him explicit images of herself with his friend. The court heard that he later went ­online looking to buy an axe, a saw and cleaning materials. Jurors rejected his claim that he bought them as a Christmas gt for his father.  And his story that she had moved away to start a new le was “riddled with ­inconsistencies, inaccuracies and lies”. The jury took three hours toa unanimous guilty verdict at Northern Ireland’s crown court, Dungannon. Denise said: “Right through the trial Miller maintained that Charlotte could still be alive. “It was horrendous. I’ve known for a long time she’s gone and the police have too. “Miller saying that made the whole ordeal worse. “We were terried he might lead the jury down the garden path to believe she wasn’t dead. Thankfully they saw through his lies.” Charlotte and Denise were born on Christmas Day , numbers six and seven in a family of . Charlotte arrived first.  “She was always the boss,” says Denise. “She was born two minutes before me and that’s the way it continued. “We were tomboys, ­always in the thick of things. Playing in the mud, climbing trees and because we were a pair we never needed anyone . We always had each other and we felt each other’s pain. “She put weight on when I was pregnant and she felt it when I was in labour.  “We had the same scars on our hands and our foreheads too.” Charlotte lived most of her le near her mother and siblings in Omagh, Co Tyrone.  But within months of meeting Miller through work in late  she moved more than  miles to live with him in the town of Moy. “She seemed besotted with him,” said Denise. “But none of us had met him. We didn’t even know where ­exactly she lived to go and visit.” It turned out none of the family had seen Charlotte for months before she died. “We’d met all of her previous boyfriends. The suddenly she’d upped and left with someone none of us knew,” said Denise.  “We should have made more of a fuss about it but we didn’t want to upset her because things could be tricky with Charlotte sometimes. I think now that he was controlling her. Denise and Charlotte fell out over a petty row in March  and never spoke again. “I thought it would blow over,” said mum-of-two Denise. “But with her being away, and me being busy with the kids, before we got a chance to make it up, it was too late.” The family became increasingly worried so they contacted Miller who agreed to meet Denise and one of her brothers in March . “Miller told us she’d got a loan out and a new passport, and he made out like she’d gone off on holiday without telling anyone. “At that time we believed him. We were actually annoyed that she’d gone off without a word to any of us. I feel so gullible now, and sickened that I bought his lies. We reported her missing that May.”  With another Christmas ­behind her – and another birthday she should have shared with her sister – Denise is fighting to stay positive that a clue will lead them to Charlotte’s grave. “In birthday cards from my brothers and sisters, they always address them to me and Charlotte because it’s not just my birthday. It’s lovely that she is never forgotten. It’s as much her birthday as it as mine.” A new law in England will soon deny murderers parolethey refuse to reveal the location of their victim’s remains. But as yet there are no such plans in Northern Ireland for a version of Helen’s Law – named after Helen McCourt, , who was killed by publican Ian Simms in .  “We’ll fight for that too,” said Denise. “We need that equivalent law, one we want to call Charlotte’s Law in Northern Ireland because leaving ­families in this state is cruel. “I’m lost without her. We all are. It’s so hard for my mum.It feels like sometimes when she looks at me she sees Charlotte.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailEvery breath Shanice Moncur takes reminds her of the day she made history. Because Shanice, , who has cystic fibrosis, was the first person in Britain to have her le saved by a set of lungs in a box. The ground-breaking medical invention has now saved  lives worldwide by keeping removed donor organs “breathing” while they are transported for transplant. And the OCS – Organ Care System – can even improve lungs not considered good enough for transplant, like those in Shanice’s chest. They had been ­rejected by four transplant centres when they arrived in front of surgeon Marius Berman at the Royal Papworth in Cambridge in November . q He realised the OCS box could make the lungs of a -year-old donor ­usable again – and Shanice, of Darlington, Co Durham, got the call. She’d been on the transplant list since April  as CF ravaged her body. By November, after marrying welder Robert Moncur, she was running out of le. “In my wedding photos I can see my collar bones sticking out – I’m ft ins and I was just over st,” she says. “It was a lovely day but I was so weak. Soon I needed oxygen every night to sleep.” Three ­-mile dashes to Papworth that summer ended in vain when donor lungs were deemed unsuitable.  Then came the fourth call. Lung and heart transplant surgeon Marius believed he could make this trip worth it using the machine that mimics the body, breathing oxygen into the lungs and feeding them with blood.It also allows doctors to ­assess and eliminate infection, excess fluid and any clotting. “When we have the lungs in the box we can test them thoroughly,” says Marius, . “And do things that will raise their quality. “The UK has one of the sickest donor populations in Europe. Fteen per cent of all organs are not usable. And for lungs it’s worse.  “So the only way forward is to try to get the best out of every set we get. “Sometimes it’s clear lungs aren’t suitable but often we are looking at organs we would call ‘marginal’. “If you have the box you can do things to make them useful. Without the transplant that day, it would have been highly unlikely the patient would have lived much longer.” Shanice only learned her case was a UK first after surgery. “I Googled the box and was wowed by how clever it was,” she said. “When I found my lungs would have otherwise gone to waste I was amazed. I’m so grateful to the medical staff and the donor and his family.  “Within a few months I was doing things I’d never done – going out with friends more, walking the dogs and exercise classes. It saved and changed my le.” Since Shanice’s op, a further four successful transplants have ­already been carried out using the box.  It is made by a US firm called TransMedics, which has also ­pioneered devices for liver and heart transplants. The company has agreed to fund the OCS – which adds around £, to the £, cost of a lung transplant – for the next year. After that, it is hoped NHS England will fund it.

When Ms Colquhuon tried to take a bottle of vodka off the yob, insisting more drink would be bad for him and his daughter, he assaulted her. North Wales Live reports Dos-Santos also pushed the woman and grabbed her hair.After she screamed, police were called to the address in Wrexham, north Wales and the thug was arrested. But the electrician was spared jail on Friday at North East Wales Magistratesapos Court and instead placed on a two-year community order. Ceri Ellis-Jones, prosecuting, said the victim had been left in severe pain and had lost her sense of taste and smell. Dos-Santos was also found to have her debit card, which had been used to make a fraudulent £ purchase. He was convicted of assault and fraud after a trial. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPond scum on toast anyone  This could be the next big food trend replacing meat and helping to save the planet, according to scientists.As the population of the world increases and more extreme weather patterns – like droughts, floods and ­heatwaves – become more frequent thanks to climate change, land for farming will get more sparse.So, the need to find new ways to boost food production is essential. Cambridge University academic Professor Alison Smith says microalgae, such as spirulina and chlorella – the green slime on the surface of stagnant water – could be the answer. And she says these so-called ­superfoods are found to be rich in B ­vitamins, iron and protein making them a viable alternative to meat, fish, eggs and dairy. It can also be grown in all sorts of ­locations, such as in snow, or even on a garden patio, opening up opportunities in overcrowded towns and cities. Typically sold in powder form, it is mixed into smoothies, yogurts and cakes, as well as being offered to NASA astronauts. There is also evidence that several hundreds of years ago, people in South America scooped spirulina out of ponds to supplement their diets. Not convinced  The trend appears to be catching on. Instagrammers have been wise to its benefits for a long time. A common recipe seen on the social media site is for Ocean Bowl, a blue-tinged plant-based yogurt fortied by spirulina, topped with fruit and nuts. Innocent Smoothies has also released a bright blue spirulina-based drink, while Aldi is flogging a soup of sweet potato laced with microalgae to give vegan customers a vitamin boost. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A teenager suffers fire-like pain doctors have compared to childbirth and suffers three-hour seizures as a result of a rare condition .After Moana Ruhfass sprained her ankle as a sporty child, she later suffered pain in her leg, hips and shoulder. This crippling agony remained undiagnosed for some time until, at , Moana was told she had Chronic Regional Pain Syndrome . It is a neurological mal of the central nervous system that results in burning, stabbing, shooting and throbbing pain. Itaposs so painful it has been dubbed suicide disease as % of sufferers take their own lives. In fact, the McGill Pain Scale measures the pain of CRPS sufferers as being even worse than childbirth. But Moana, now  and from Australia, battles the condition bravely. I also feel pain like someone is constantly stabbing me, pain like itaposs lightning striking and painful pins and needles, she said today. It can get to the point where I canapost even stand the wind on my skin or moving at all. I sometimes canapost even shower my foot because even a drop of water would have me screaming. Moanaaposs condition deteriorated to the point she became confined in a wheelchair in , reports Daily Mail Australia .She spent  excruciating hours a day in physiotherapy, as therapists tried to desensitise and reset the pain perception in her neuro pathway. The therapy was partially successful, and enabled her to walk again, however, the unbearable pain she experiences remained constant.  However Moana added: I have good and bad days. On my good days I still have constant pain but I get used to it and manage it. But on my bad days I canapost even bear someone touching me. The weight of a blanket and lying down hurts but itaposs better than being on my feet. Moanaaposs father Manfred said her emotional and physical wellbeing is slowly deteriorating. Eve said she even thought about ending it all as she lay helpless on her bathroom floor during the horror incident on Thursday. Her granny who suffers from dementia was next door as her granddaughter screamed and banged on the doors and walls for hours on end hoping to be released. Posting on social media yesterday, she said: I came upstairs to find six men with balaclavas in my house. They put knives to my neck and screwdrivers to my eyes. They threw bleach on me and asked where the jewellery and money was. I’ve never ever felt as terried in my le. I kept pleading with them, aposplease donapost hurt my grannyapos. They then dragged me by the hair into a tiny toilet ensuite in the back bedroom, which has no window, locked me in and took the key. The thugs took Eveaposs iPhone XS leaving her unable to ring for help. Her confused granny was sadly unable to help as she couldnapost understand how to use the phone to call . She continued: I wrote notes with mascara and put them under the door to try and help her remember how to use the phone but it was no use. I was locked in the toilet for  hours. I was absolutely freezing. My poor dogs were going mad. I got my granny to get into the bed beside the toilet I was in and she went to sleep. I started banging a hole in the wall to try and get out but it was no use. story: Workers at Angus Council are trialling a fresh approach to stubbing out cigarette litter in Arbroath.They have installed an eye-catching “ballot bin” on the High Street to encourage smokers to ditch their butts responsibly.A series of questions will be printed on the bin throughout the year, with smokers able to vote yes or no with their cigarette butts.Waste strategy officer Peter Moug said: “The businesses in the High Street are all behind this campaign.“Many have been displaying posters in their windows, too, to encourage smokers to use the litter bins provided rather than drop butts on the pavement.“We hope this fun ballot box will attract attention and get people thinking about where their cigarette litter should go.”

title: dundee 0 2 inverness dismal dee drop to fourth with ict defeat
story: Dundee dropped to fourth in the Championship table as they fell to a - defeat to Inverness at Dens Park.First-half goals from Aaron Doran and James Keatings did the damage as John Robertson#s Caley Jags strengthened their grip on second spot.Ayr winning at Dunfermline meant the Dark Blues dropped to the fourth and final promotion play-off spot,  points behind leaders Dundee United.Dee boss James McPake stuck with the same line-up which earned a point in the Dundee derby with -year-old Fin Robertson starting in the middle of the park after a terric display at Tannadice.Inverness were the first to threaten but Nikolay Todorov could only head Miles Storey#s cross over the bar after three minutes.Caley skipper Carl Tremarco went closer on nine minutes as he got on the end of another Storey cross after a period of pressure. However, Dark Blues keeper Jack Hamilton gathered the header comfortably.Hamilton then made a smart stop from a whipped Keatings free-kick minutes later as the visitors continued to push for the opener.On  minutes Charlie Trafford forced a routine save out of Hamilton before, just a minute later, Inverness got the goal their play deserved.In acres of space down the right, full-back Shaun Rooney had the freedom of Dens Park to pick out Doran in the centre of the box and the Irish attacker duly lashed home from  yards.On  minutes, ICT were two to the good. From their own corner, Dundee compounded to lose possession and allowed the Highlanders to break.Former Dundee United man Keatings led the charge and finished the counter attack off himself, coolly slotting beyond a helpless Hamilton in the home goal.The Dark Blues huffed and puffed for the remainder of a dismal first half for them but were unable to lay a glove on Inverness as the boos rang out among the sizeable home support on the half-time whistle.Four minutes into the second period, Dundee forced Mark Ridgers into his first save of the afternoon as the ICT goalie stooped to turn Jordan Marshall#s long-range effort behind for a corner.Jordan McGhee was next to test Ridgers, firing in a dipping effort just before the hour mark, but the Caley stopper was able to gather.Moments later, Paul McGowan#s header from a deep Sean Mackie cross forced Ridgers to tip over as the Dee sought a way back into the contest.On  minutes, Kane Hemmings laid in Marshall but the left-back saw his effort from  yards deflected behind.Inverness# front four continued to look threatening but, largely, the Dee defence kept them quiet in the second .However, McPake#s men were unable to carve a way through an organised ICT defence with the rookie boss cutting a frustrated and under-pressure figure throughout.With Ayr and Dunfermline to face next, Dundee will certainly need to perform a lot betterthey are to stay in the mix for the promotion play-offs come the end of the season.Dundee XI : HamiltonKerr, Meekings , McGhee, Marshall Robertson, Dorrans, McGowan, MackieJohnson , Hemmings.Subs not used: Ferrie , Forster, Byrne, Moore and Cameron.Inverness XI : RidgersRooney, Donaldson, McHattie, TremarcoTrafford , Vincent StoreyKeatings Doran Todorov .Subs not used: Mackay , McCart, Curry and MacGregor.Referee: Don Robertson.Att: ,.

title: lawrence shankland has full focus on united as they hunt title
story: He’s a wanted man in the January transfer window but Dundee United hitman Lawrence Shankland says it would be criminal for him to take his eyes off the prize as they hunt down the Championship title.United sit  points clear at the top of the table with  games left to play and -goal talisman Shanks insists his full focus is on getting the Tangerines over the line, not the speculation linking him with a move away from Tannadice.The -year-old Scotland striker has been linked with teams both sides of the border but he says until United tell him dferently, it’s all guns blazing in their quest for silverware.“I don’t take interest in it, to be honest,” he said.“I’ve said before that until someone from Dundee United comes to speak to me about it then it’s none of my business really.“It’s all just speculation and rumours, so I won’t take any interest in it at all.“If the time comes when somebody does speak to me then I’ll deal with it then but it’s not something I’m getting too caught up with.“I’m really enjoying it here and the team’s going well, firing at the top of the league, so I don’t see why I’d be choking to get out.“We need to be looking forward now because we’ve got ourselves a good gap at the top.“It would be silly for us to ignore that because we’ve got ourselves in a good position but that’s only the case right now.“We need to kick on and keep winning games because,we keep doing that, the closer we’ll get and the less wins we’ll need.“Until that point we’ll just need to keep taking it one game at a time, batting them off and picking up three points most weeks.”Shankland will come up against his former boss at Ayr United, Ian McCall, as the Terrors head to Glasgow to take on his current side Partick Thistle tomorrow.And he admits United are wary of a team who have won three out of their last five in the league.“It’s going to be a tough game, especially down there,” he added.“Last time we were - down and had to come back after half-time. Up here it was tight at - until about the hour mark and then we got the goal.“From going in front in both games it was all about defending and seeing it out. We know what to expect from Partick, it’s going to be a hard game.“I know Ian McCall well and he always has his teams set up properly, no matter where he goes.“Fingers crossed we can get a result but we need to be wary. The squad and players they’ve got have quality but maybe just haven’t picked up until now.“They’ve turned it around since the start of the season, so it will be a tough fixture again.”Without a goal in his last two games, by his remarkably high standards, Shankland is experiencing a drought he’s keen to end. vw, px"  He said: “Last season I did the same, scoring loads up until January then I picked up a wee injury and only scored one every two games, so it wasn’t a bad rate!“Everybody jumped on the bandwagon that I hadn’t scored but it was one in two, soI can do that for the rest of the season I’d be quite happy again.“The main thing for me is getting back on the scoresheet this week.”However, he is pleased to see others like Nicky Clark now chipping in.“It was always going to happen, it was never going to be one guy scoring the goals the full time.“We know that the boys will chip in. It just took Clarky to get his first goal and then he kicked on from there.“It’s the same for a lot of people but I don’t really care who scores, to be honest, as long as we’re picking up three points each week I’ll be quite happy.”

title: partick thistle 1 4 dundee united perfect hat trick from shankland sends utd 17 clear
story: Dundee United went  points clear at the top of the Championship as a perfect hat-trick from Lawrence Shankland sent them on their way to aShankland opened the scoring at Firhill with a header on  minutes, with strikes on either foot coming in the second half after Adrian Sporle had made it - on the stroke of half-time.Kenny Miller pulled a late goal back for the Jags but three points means the Tangerines are now  points clear of Inverness at the top of the Championship.United showed two changes from last weekend#s win at Queen of the South with captain Mark Reynolds and new boy Dillon Powers coming in for his debut in place of Jamie Robson and Calum Butcher.Partick had an early penalty shout for handball but referee Willie Collum waved away the claims and instead pointed for a corner.Lawrence Shankland headed straight at Scott Fox in the home goal from a deep Nicky Clark free-kick moments later as the game began to settle down.Benjamin Siegrist in the United net had the simplest of saves from James Penrice on  minutes before Declan Glass dragged a shot wide up the other end.The cut-up pitch, due to the wet conditions in Glasgow, saw much of the build-up from both teams bogged down but, of the good football on show, it was the Terrors with the lion#s share.Glass troubled Fox again on  minutes with a dipping, bouncing effort. However, the best chance of the opening half hour was the Jags#.A lung-busting run from Dario Zanatta nearly paid idends for the hosts but Siegrist#s legs foiled the Canadian inside the penalty area.Paul Watson saw a header drt wide from a Clark delivery before Shankland teed up Glass, only for the -year-old to fire wide once again.Zanatta once more came close on  minutes, this time glancing a Joe Cardle delivery towards goal but into the grateful arms of Siegrist.Just a minute later, the Tangerines No  was again the thorn in Thistle#s side.On his own in the six-yard box, Kenny Miller picked up on Zanatta#s cross only for the big Swiss keeper to pull off a wonder save to deny Miller from close range.Clark forced Fox into action with an audacious effort from some  yards before the former Dundee keeper halted Shankland close in.However, moments later, Shanks wasn#t to be denied his nd United goal of the season.From a Clark corner, the Scotland star had the freedom of the Thistle box to guide a header beyond a helpless Fox for - on  minutes.And Shankland was at the heart of United#s second. Picking up on the ball in the middle of the Partick half, he drove forward and slipped in Glass.The United kid#s cross-cum-shot found Adrian Sporle with the simplest of tasks to tap home unopposed for his first league goal for the club.After a frenetic first period, the second  took a while to get going but it was Ian McCall#s side on the front foot.Just before the hour-mark, the impressive Reece Cole made a powerful run into the box before his effort won the Jags a corner.However, it was United who got the scoring under way in the second half and took control with the first chance of note in the period.And it was that man Shankland again as he went on a terric -yard solo run into the Partick box before calmly slotting beyond Fox for his second of the afternoon and the Terrors# third.Peter Pawlett completed his comeback from injury on  minutes when he replaced Paul Watson.And, just a minute later, his first involvement in the game was to tee up Shankland for his third, completing a perfect hat-trick by thundering a left-foot drive into the top corner to send the ,-strong visiting support wild.One of few worries for United on the afternoon came on  minutes when Clark had to limp off injured, to be replaced by Adam King.Miller netted a late consolation for Thistle on  minutes but Robbie Neilson#s men took all the points and another step towards sealing the title.Partick Thistle XI : FoxWilliamson , Saunders, O#Ware , Penrice Cardle , Bannigan, Cole, Zanatta Jones , Miller.Subs not used: Sneddon , Harkins, Slater and Mansell.Dundee United XI : SiegristSmith, Watson , Connolly, ReynoldsPowers Appere, Glass , Clark , Sporle Shankland.Subs not used: Deniz , Sow, Stanton and Freeman.Referee: Willie Collum.Att: , .

story: A Ceilidh celebrating the culture of two countries is to take place in the city later this month.The Polish Scottish Ceilidh is being held from pm until midnight on January  at the Blue Lamp.Danse McCabre the ceilidh band and guests will play Scottish and Polish songs and dances throughout the evening.Guests will also be able to enjoy traditional Polish and Scottish food-tasting included in the ticket price.The Polish Scottish Song and Story Group will sing traditional songs from both countries.Standard tickets are priced at £, with concession tickets at £ and students at £.The event forms part of the annual Polish Scottish Mini Festival which is run by the Polish Association Aberdeen and includes a range of activities during January and February.The festival closes with a Warsaw Village Band concert on February  at Aberdeen Arts Centre.

title: end of an era as aecc arena be flattened
story: Work to knock down Aberdeen#s former exhibition centre is expected to begin in the coming weeks.Aberdeen City Council submitted a building warrant to demolish existing buildings at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centrein Bridge of Don, alongside agents Fairhurst.The site is no longer in use following the opening of the PJ Live arena in August last year.The multi-million-pound state-of-the-art event complex, which is in Bucksburn, now hosts all major events. vw, px"  The AECC first opened its doors in  and comprised of conference facilities and a multi-purpose arena.It has now been permanently closed.A building warrant was submitted in September to demolish buildings at the site including the main arena, which has now been approved by the local authority.Aberdeen City Council co-leader Douglas Lumsden said now the building warrant has been granted, the “intention” would be for that work to start “immediately”.He added: “That might include internal works first which people won’t be able to see.”As well as the removal of the old main arena building, the covered walkway that connects to the section of the conference centre next to the Holiday Inn Express will also be removed.It is expected that the value of the work to be undertaken will be around £,.The warrant has an expiry date of January   and all work must be completed by then.It is understood that the remaining conference centre will be retained as well as the nearby park-and-ride facility.Talks regarding the future use of the site are still ongoing.Plans were previously submitted to the local authority by developers Henry Boot in May  for the land, which hoped to create a mixed use development including approximately  residential units, properties for commercial and business use, a recycling centre and park-and-ride facility.The application is still pending and there was a number of documents uploaded on to the site in , along with a letter of objection received last year.It stated: “The site would have been better used as a new north-east HQ and training hub for Police Scotland with Queen Street being disposed of.“There would be ample space to create a specialist training facility, which Police Scotland does not have anywhere north of the central belt.”Discussions have also been under way with the King’s Community Church over the site, with the church keen to move from its base on King Street.The church began in  with a small gathering before it moved to the city centre church in  where it has remained.An Aberdeen City Council spokeswoman said: “A building warrant to demolish the arena at the old AECC and a covered walkway to the adjacent hotel has been approved by the planning authority.”
