title: bid-help-save-historic-golf-courses-climate-change
story: Scientists are to carry out a complete audit of the coastal golf courses of Great Britain and Ireland, and with five courses chosen in consultation with golfs governing body, the RA to provide a more focused examination.It forms part of a wider initiative being spearheaded by the RA that has raised concerns about the effects of climate change on coastal courses.One of the courses that researchers from the University of St Andrews will focus on is the home of golf, the Old Course in St Andrews.:The Cool List - Scottish golf courses every fan must playScientists estimate almost pound million worth of damage could be caused by coastal erosion around Scotland alone.The Climate Coalition, which represents more than  organisations in the Britain studying the effects of climate change, in a  report, said that golf faced an "unexpected threat" from even a slight rise in sea levels, and Open Championship venues such as St Andrews could be under water by .The report, which added that six of the UKrsquos seven wettest years on record have occurred since , predicted that ldquogolf courses will crumble into the sea.ldquoClimate change is already impacting our ability to play and watch the sports we love, said the report, adding that extreme weather is a factor in declining participation and lost revenue.One in six Scottish golf courses were on the coast, where they are at the most risk of erosion due to rising sea levels.In , it emerged that owners of the -year-old Montrose Golf Links, was considering launching a crowdfunding campaign to raise pound million to save what is reputedly the fth oldest golf course in the world that is losing more than two metres a year to the sea.By then it had already had to move three of its holes.In a study published in  Fraser Milne, a post-doctoral researcher at Dundee University, estimated that the North Sea has crept m towards Montrose in the previous  years.The new three-year project, led by Professor Bill Austin, of the University of St Andrews is part of an action plan by the RA . which granted pound, towards the research looking into wider challenges facing the sportrsquos sustainability.Mr Austin said St Andrews would be their first detailed study site, while a further four are being picked based on sea-level trends around the whole of the United Kingdom."We will develop some of the project methods here in St Andrews, in collaboration with local green keepers from the Links Trust, before extending out to other sites, both here in Scotland and across the wider GB  Ireland network," he said."Irsquom not a keen golfer ndash so there is no danger of the project only visiting championship courses ndash indeed wersquove discussed with the RA that we need to understand conditions across a range of course types and resourcing levels."We will use a GISapproach to deliver the full-scale picture and eventually we hope to deliver climate mitigation and adaptation advice from the project itself."Irsquom excited to be working on a project that can make a dference and delighted that the RA have seen fit to fund this research."In , the Royal Dornoch Golf Club supported a pioneering project that it was hoped would help prevent part of its course succumbing to coastal erosion.A number of gaps in the saltmarsh habitat in the Dornoch Firth meant part of Royal Dornochrsquos Struie Course had been vulnerable to flooding and being lost to the power of the waves.The new project aimed to transplant hundreds of greenhouse-grown native saltmarsh plants to help restore the natural defences.Dr Clare Maynard, a research scientist at St Andrews University and chair of the Marine Alliance for Science and TechnologyCoastal Forum, was the project manager of Green Shores, the pound, scheme promoting the restoration of saltmarshes.And Royal Dornoch Golf Club provided pound, a year for three years towards the project to help safeguard the th fairway on its Struie Course, which had been under attack from the sea.Coastal change and its impact on golf courses was identied last year by the RA as one of a handful of priority issues to be investigated over the next three years.The Coastal Change Action Plan is a key component of its Golf Course , an initiative to consider the impact, both positive and negative, of the changing climate, resource constraints and regulation on golf course condition and playability.And RA report into the climate change issues facing golf courses seen by the Herald says that % of the Northern Ireland coast and % of England and Wales is "armoured" - the practice of using physical structures to protect shorelines from coastal erosion.But in Scotland it is just %."Today, coastal management is covered by a complex patchwork of legislation and is carried out by a iety of organisations with dferent responsibilities," said the report."Current shoreline management tends to be reacting and poorly structured in some areas and continuation of current practice will lead to coastal degradation and loss of amenity value."Shoreline Management Plans have the ambition to provide a structured and consistent framework and this may be better achieved when they are refreshed in coming years.": Climate change threatens to kill off golf in the country where it was first playedProfessor Bill Austin said: ldquoThe oceans and seas that surround many of the worldrsquos top golf courses play a vital role in their future viability. Many are already seeing the impact of coastal erosion and flooding brought on by more storms and rising sea levels as a result of climate change."This research will allow us to consider all climate-related factors that will have an ever-lasting effect on the Home of Golf."Our research will also look at the blue carbon opportunities and the role of long-term carbon storage in Scotlandrsquos coastal habitats surrounding golf courses. If we can protect these carbon-rich ecosystems we can prevent the release of greenhouse gases that would otherwise contribute to global warming, support their rich bioersity and improve their resilience to future sea-level rise.Steve Isaac, sustainability director at The RA, said, ldquoThis marks our initial investment in research, education and communication projects in support of our Golf Course  initiative. We are funding these projects to develop best practice in sustainability and provide solutions to golf course managers that will help to sustain and improve the standard of golf course conditions and playability for the benefit of those who enjoy the sport.ldquoThe results of the projects being funded will contribute signicantly towards meeting the aims of Golf Course  and provide insights to the golf industry as we consider how to address the challenges and opportunities presented by a changing climate, resource constraints and regulation on golf course management.

title: kevin-mckenna-harry-meghan-can-pay-way-cant-rest-royal-family
story: Mr and Mrs Sussexrsquos desire to become ldquofinancially independent like the common people is admirable and it surely behoves all of us who admire the Royal Familyrsquos selfless devotion to the country to help them achieve this happy state. Most of those who have become unemployed and have no immediate prospect of another secure income are compelled to introduce a measure of austerity between jobs. This shouldnrsquot be a problem for the Sussexes.The duchess brought a few million to the union following a successful acting career in the United States while Harry inherited poundm from his mother, the late Princess Diana and poundm from his dear old Granny Betty, the Queen Mother. When you throw in the annual pound.m the couple have been receiving from Prince Charles the rocky road to financial independence becomes a little less so. If this couple really are genuine about seeking financial independence as the term is understood by the rest of us then the transition from ornamental popinjays to tax-paying citizens and cutting their cloth accordingly shouldnrsquot present them with many dficulties.Andthey were to feel that a poundk estimated annual rental of their pound.m Frogmore Cottage home is a bit steep then nothingrsquos stopping them moving into a more modest home, perhaps something in the more manageable poundm category. Hell, why not push the boat out and see about taking out a mortgage  Irsquom sure also that Meghan could make a few commercials to tide them over while her husband finds his feet.Harry, like the rest of the royals, has no obvious talents and may find it dficult to source suitably paid employment by his own endeavours. This family isnrsquot exactly blessed with charisma or discernible leadership skills. And such dubious qualications wersquore all led to believe they gained on their own havenrsquot been tested in any workplace where promotion and status is gained on merit.In the UK, though, where deference, supplication and genuflection to this family is almost absolute, Harry shouldnrsquot find much dficulty in obtaining a few non-executive directorships. Just so long as hersquos not expected to exhibit flair at anything in particular. Irsquod be less confident about paid speaking engagements, mind you.The anger that this has all caused within the Royal Family is easy to understand and the corgis must be having a torrid time of it right now. The royal lackeys in the right-wing press suggest that, having granted them their multi-million pound wedding their beautul home and royal titles, the firm is aghast at Harry and Meghanrsquos ingratitude. I feel their pain. The long-term implications of the couplersquos new-found sense of freedom for the House of Windsor are seriously catastrophic. If this couple can look after themselves then why canrsquot the rest of them If you believe the UK Government, the task of extricating a nation of  million souls and thousands of laws from the European Union will take barely a year. Removing the public teat from the mouths of this gilded outfit and finding them suitable careers advice shouldnrsquot be too onerous. After that it becomes a matter of taking the assorted royal palaces and castles back into public ownership.Perhaps the younger members of the Royal Family could put their knowledge of these places to good use and become tour guides. Being a reasonable chiel Irsquod perhaps permit them to hang on to one of the royal residences and convert it into an eventide home for royal codgerdom. Irsquod only stipulate that once a year they agree to a fly-on-the-wall Christmas special for the BBC, presented by Nicholas Witchell whom Prince Charles once described as ldquothat awful man.A quantum of mince has been written about the Duchy of Cornwall, the inherited vehicle by which Prince Charles lsquoearnsrsquo his multi-million-pound income. This huge estate makes the prince the biggest landowner in England and we are asked to believe the lie that it also makes him self-sufficient. As Harry and Meghan obtain the bulk of their income from the duchy then the lie extends to them too.The Duchy of Cornwall was established in  by Edward III as a gt to his son, Edward, Prince of Wales, also known as The Black Prince. The Prince of Wales does not extract his millions from this vast landholding through any merit or talent of his own. He is able to employ squads of professionals to help him and give credence to the subsistence lie.Only the oldest surviving son of the monarch gets to use it as his own personal cash cow. No women can get their mitts on it and no Catholics either. In st century Britain we allow this family of property thieves to prevent Catholics contaminating their bloodline, unless of course they first renounce their faith.Our maintenance of this family in their palaces and their multi-million pound lestyles mocks any pretensions this country has to values of equality, justice and honesty. For how can we proclaim these virtues and propel our young people towards them when we permit medieval feudalism and grievous discrimination to flourish at the heart of British society We always want the next generation to learn from the mistakes of past ones and to become better than us. This, though, becomes a pointless exercise when we seem to celebrate and bow down to the Royal Family and its ancient, unearned privileges. Here, mediocrity is rewarded entitlement is encouraged and true merit is scorned.If Prince Harry and Meghan Markel genuinely want to decouple from this seedy fiefdom then I wish them every success. The nation wonrsquot be convinced, though, until we see a set of accounts that doesnrsquot include income from the civil list or the spoils of th century conquest. And until we lose the rest of them Britain will never be entitled to call itself a modern, civilised country.

title: tom-gordon-scottish-labours-position-worse-thought
story: A Wisden-like slew of statistics, itrsquos invaluable for shining a light on the overlooked details of the result.The latest contains some fascinating nuggets about the  vote in Scotland, especially about Labourrsquos fortunes.The partyrsquos Scottish executive, which meets in Glasgow today to discuss its response to that thrashing, might want a stf drink before reading it.For Scottish Labourrsquos result is even worse than it looked at first glance.The headlines were the loss of six of seven MPs, saved from a total wipe-out by Ian Murray in Edinburgh South, and its vote share falling from . per cent to .%, putting it third behind the Tories.While Labour only just came third in , it was decisively beaten by the Tories in , the gap between the two widening from . to . per cent.But look deeper and you really see how far the party has sunk.There have been five general elections in Scotland on the same boundaries, so some gruesome trends are discernible.In  and , Labour won  and  of Scotlandrsquos  seats with vote shares of .% and .% respectively.Many of the safest Labour seats in the UK were then in Scotland. The partyrsquos biggest majority in  was , in Coatbridge. Tony Blairrsquos majority in Sedgefield was only the third largest.In every Scottish seat, Labour candidates always polled at least %The SNP tsunami of  obviously changed that, but not just by washing away every Labour MP bar Mr Murray.There was new phenomenon.Labour effectively became electorally irrelevant in several Scottish seats.Candidates started losing deposits for the first time in decades.Labour lost three deposits - after polling less than % - across the entire UK in . All three were in Scotland.Labourrsquos share of the vote also fell below % in a dozen Scottish seats.The picture briefly improved in Mr Corbynrsquos half-decent loss of .There were no lost deposits in the UK, and Labourrsquos vote share was down to single figures in only three Scottish seats.But last month those worrying trends for Labour reasserted themselves.In , Labour won m votes in Scotland. Last month it was half that.The party lost  deposits across the UK. Seven were in Scotland.Its vote fell in all  Scottish seats, and went below % in  - single figure support in a third of the country.The Tories also lost seats and vote share in Scotland. But in only two seats did they drop into single figures, and there were no lost deposits.The SNP, which had an overall vote share of %, only fell below % in a single seat, Mr Murrayrsquos, and even there they managed a respectable .%.Labourrsquos vote was squeezed left, right and centre. It lost deposits in seats won by the SNP, the Tories and LibDems.It previous supporters abandoned it to vote tactically or just plain abandoned it.In Dumfries  Galloway, which it won in  with .% of the vote, Labour was down to a humbling .%.In large parts of Scotland, Labour is disappearing from the electoral map.A fallen giant, its carcass is being systematically stripped clean by other parties scavenging for votes.So what to do  Scottish leader Richard Leonard has announced he is leading a review of the election, with the party told to expect some ldquohard lessons.Herersquos a hard lesson for him. He should step aside from the review because hersquos part of the problem.In two colourless years as leader, he has lost both his MEPs, six of his MPs, andhe carries on as before, a good lot of his MSPs in  as well.He has just not connected with voters.He never tried to step out of Mr Corbynrsquos shadow. Worse, he seems more fired up by Labour party history than your tomorrow.Irsquove yet to hear his big vision for Scotland in the st century. But Irsquove lost count of his reveries about Mary Barbour and the Glasgow rent strikes of  years ago, or eulogies for Keir Hardie and other sepia-tinted ghosts.Itrsquos a comfort blanket. Therersquos not a single vote in any of it. Not one.The review will also cover the partyrsquos ldquoconstitutional offer. This boils down to whether it supports a second referendum on independence.Mr Leonard was initially opposed to Indyref, then caved in to Mr Corbyn and John McDonnell when they said Labour shouldnrsquot stand in the way of it.But now party members may be asked whether to actively embrace Indyref, as the outgoing general secretary of the STUC, Grahame Smith, has advised.There has been some harking back to the s, when Labourrsquos offer was a Scottish Parliament subject to a referendum. Back then the party was behind both the end and the means.However for Scottish Labour to back Indyref, but not back independence, would be a far harder trick to pull off.Hence Mr Leonard floating the idea of a multiple-choice referendum, with independence and devo max or federalism against the status quo.This might seem like a clever fudge.The SNP and Greens would back independence in such a scenario, Labour and the LibDems more devolution, leaving the Tories as the party offering Scotland an empty plate.But would voters really be bowled over by it  Ever greater devolution is already the direction of travel for Holyrood. The public expects it.Presenting it as a great leap forward requiring yet another trip to the polls is unlikely to earn much thanks.The setting up of Holyrood was a huge change. Independence obviously would be. But more powers Federalism would also require parallel devolution in Englandrsquos regions. Scottish Labour canrsquot guarantee that.Kezia Dugdale tried it, touting a ldquonew Act of Union as a federal riposte to independence. It sank without trace.Then there are the mechanics of a three-way vote, and the row over them.A first-past-the-post system could, in theory, deliver independencejust over a third of voters backed it. Under the single transferable vote, it could win out with even fewer first preferences.In the end, the need for a clear and authoritative result would make a re-run of rsquos binary choice between independence or the Union inevitable.Labour members shouldnrsquot be gulled into thinking there is a soft third-way optionIndyref ever comes to pass.Nicola Sturgeon doesnrsquot want Devo Max on the ballot. A decade ago, it might have seemed akin to a win for SNP, but not after Brexit. A Devo Max Scotland would still be outside the EU.In the panicky aftermath of defeat, a new constitutional offer might seem a key step in Scottish Labourrsquos recovery. But its problems are not so easily fixed.Its fall owes more to socio-economic and demographic change eroding its base and a decade of inadequate leadership both sides of the border.Ed Miliband and Jeremy Corbyn couldnrsquot cut it. Iain Gray and Johann Lamont couldnrsquot dent Alex Salmond, and Ms Dugdale and Mr Leonard have been no match for Nicola Sturgeon.Scottish Labourrsquos best hope is an electable UK leader who can earn the party a second look from voters.Adopting a new position on Indyref didnrsquot help Mr Corbyn and it wonrsquot make a winner out of Mr Leonard.

title: 300-mile-route-via-dumfries-ayr-new-north-coast-500
story: But now tourism bosses are turning the spotlight on the south-west of Scotland in the latest Route -style campaign to lure visitors to the regionrsquos beauty spots.The campaign by Visit South West Scotlandaims to raise awareness of the circular -mile South West Coastal touring route through Dumfries and Galloway and South Ayrshire.The SWV was designed by Motorcycle Scotland and adapted by tourist chiefs to take in more local attractions.: North Coast  taken over by Scotlands biggest landownerThe road trip takes in the south-west coastline from Ayr to Cairngaan via Stranraer and Portpatrick, before passing along the south of Scotland through Wigtown, Kirkcudbright and Castle Douglas, then heading inland to Dumfries.From there the remainder of the route loops round via Lockerbie, Moffat, Sanquhar, New Cumnock, Dalmellington and Maybole.The new digital campaign, funded with pound, from VisitScotland, is geared to making visitors ldquofall in love with south-west Scotland by showcasing aspects of the route which offer particular appeal to the key target markets such as its scenery, wildle and adventure sports.Ian McAndrew, chairman of Visit South West Scotland, said: ldquoThe south-west of Scotland is a special place, it has so much to offer, especially to lovers of the great outdoors and that is a message we are working hard to get out there.ldquoAs a trade organisation, collaboration is at the core of what we do, we rely on our members and our strategic partners to get behind our efforts to make a real dference to tourism in the South West.ldquoTherefore when VisitScotland agreed to support our promotional campaign for the South West Coastal , a touring route that encourages visitors to explore our region, we were delighted.Tourist bosses will market the SWC Touring Road Route to the rest of the UK and Ireland in an online drive featuring short films, images and itineraries, and promotional activity on YouTube, Facebook and Instagram by ldquoinfluencers ndash people with tens of thousands of social media followers.They expect the campaign to reach more than , people via social media and at least double traffic to the South West Coastal  landing page on the VSWS website.: Burns worth over poundm to Scottish economyPaula Ward, VisitScotland Regional Leadership Director, said: ldquoWith its stunning coastal and inland landscapes, peaceful atmosphere and fantastic attractions, the south-west of Scotland is a great visitor destination and the SWC is the perfect route for experiencing it.ldquoIrsquom thrilled we were able to support this exciting new campaign and I canrsquot wait to see the outputs.ldquoAt VisitScotland we want to champion collaboration, spearhead digital innovation and promote local areas to make sure every part of Scotland enjoys the benefits of tourism.The latest tourism drive comes after the success of the North Coast , which was developed as a way to bring visitors to hidden parts of the Scottish Highlands and give economic benefits to struggling communities.The -mile route ndash dubbed Scotlandrsquos answer to Route , the famous US highway linking Chicago to Santa Monica ndash was essentially a rebranding of an existing system of roads that had been around for decades.It begins at Inverness Castle before heading north to John OrsquoGroats and looping back around along the north-west coast via Durness, Lochinver and Applecross.It takes in breathtaking countryside, including the infamous hairpin bends of the Bealach na Ba, secluded northern beaches, distilleries, smokehouses and farm shops, and was recently named the most spectacular drive in the UK.Visitors can have their NC ldquopassport stamped at attractions along the route.Its twisting single-track road have proven particularly popular with cyclists and motorists, including the owners of supercars, although residents living along the route have complained that its popularity was causing disruption. There have been calls for a Highland tourist tax to help the wider region cash in on the venture.The North Coast  company was initially set up by Prince Charlesrsquo North Highland Initiative to promote the existing road internationally.It was later taken over by Wildland Ventures Ltd, a conservation-based company owned by Scotlandrsquos largest private landowner, Anders Hoch Povlsen, the Danish Asos clothing billionaire, and his we Anne Povlsen.

title: couple-drive-van-25-000-miles-en-route-scotland
story: However it was not all plain drivingfor Joss Quilty during his -countrytrek as he narrowly missed a suicide bomb attack as he made his waythrough Pakistan.Mr Quilty made the trip after hefound he could not part with his old and battered Toyota Land Cruiser when he decided toto the UK ndash so he opted to drive it all the way ndash for nearly , miles.He spent nearly  months in his beloved van over three continents, and nearly came to a tragic end with thenear- miss from the suicide bomber.The -year-old decided to take on the epic journey with his girlfriend Romy Romagnoli, also .The pair shipped the pound, car to Malaysia and began the trek fromthere ndash arriving in the UK in timefor Christmas.They passed through Thailand, Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, India, Nepal, Pakistan and Iran before reaching Europe.They then worked their way across Azerbaijan, Georgia, Turkey, Bulgaria, North Macedonia, Albania, Montenegro, Italy, Austria, Germany, Luxembourg, Belgium and France before ending up in Thornbury, Gloucestershire. They will continue their trip back to Scotland later.To make the dream trip extra special, Mr Quilty proposed to Ms Romagnoli when they ed.He said: ldquoI had bought this old Toyota and wanted to keep it. Itrsquos a really good car and Irsquom just amazed it was possible.ldquoOur budget was very tight for the whole trip. We tried to sleep in the vehicle the whole way, with mattresses in the back.ldquoRomy and I were very much in this together in making decisions ndash to drive the car back, choosing the route, splitting the money  .ldquoThere is no way I could have done the trip without her. Shersquos tough and very keen on a challenge.ldquoThere is danger but everyone you meet is so kind and welcoming, thatrsquos what makes it.ldquoWe had to have armed guards for some parts ndash when you follow the border of Pakistan and Afghanistan.ldquoWe had a close shave with the Taliban there, after leaving a military base. We had a guy with an AK- with us in the car. We were driving along when he leaned forward and told us to drive fast because there was a female suicide bomber nearby.ldquoI was s******* it ndash the car couldonly do a maximum of mph! I donrsquot know what happened next. Wenever heard.Mr Quilty also had problems getting into trouble-hit Iran with his UK passport, although his girlfriendhad no worries because of her Italian credentials.He said: ldquoIt was really dficult. It took me a few months of effort to get a visa and ,.But the pair said the majority of people they encountered were lovely and willing to do anything for them.He said: ldquoThey all wanted to help,even though they had nothing. Itrsquos the people you meet that make the places.ldquoOne woman brought out her baby to look at me because it had not seen a white person before.The accountant bought the red car while he was living and working inNew Zealand. He and his girlfriendthen spent another pound, on renovations because it had suffered some wear and tear since its manufacture in .The couple were inspired to take on the challenge after getting fed up hearing their friends talk about their experiences.Mr Quilty said: ldquoAll our friends are adventurers. We would go to the puband they would make you think lsquoI should be doing something with my lersquo.ldquoAfter that we just decided to do it.He proposed to social worker Romy in a pub when they finally arrived back home, after five years together.She said yes and the couple have now decided to move up to Scotland ndash with the Toyota.But they are hoping to do another trip before they go, possible travelling from Alaska, America, to Argentina.Mr Quilty said: ldquoWalking around Bristol doesnrsquot exactly have the same appeal. The people we saw, the waythey live [when travelling] ... wecame back and people were arguing about vegan sausage rolls. Itwas depressing.

title: rab-mcneil-sands-time-message-history-visitors-outer-space
story: First, there were the Finns. Their relatively young prime minister, Sanna Marin, aged  and three-quarters, has called for a four-day working week and six-hour days to let people spend more time with their families and have more of a wossname: a le.This is radical stuff, and Britain and the USA are expected to send tanks to the country immediately to put a stop to such nonsense. Indeed, didnrsquot Labourrsquos manesto or programme or policy on the hoof indicate a similar aspiration causing much frothing at the mouth in right-wing newspaper offices up and also down the land Itrsquos something you should always remember. All the talk about freedom, sovereignty, civil rights, this liberty, that liberty and parliamentary politics generally is just froth. All that really matters is the economy, by which is meant profiting from the labour of others. Threaten that with strikes or shorter days and you will feel hellip The Wrath.But thatrsquos old hat. The six-hour day is new hat, though I think it already happens in Sweden, where itrsquos reported to have created happier, wealthier and more productive employees. Well, therersquos a surprise. In Japan, experimenting with a three-day weekend increased productivity at Microsoft there by . per cent.Britain, unfortunately, tends to believe that the only good worker is an unhappy worker. Itrsquos deeply felt that this is a natural law. I remember, about  years ago, a group of Danes coming to our then workplace and being appalled by the long, macho hours and presenteeism, all of which was just stretching out incompetence.Our bemused visitors could sense this right away. Longer hours did not mean that more got done. My memory of offices and the eight-hour day is that at least six and a half of them were wasted.Unlike we Britlanders, Scandinavians have a reputation for getting their work done and leaving the office early. But do we really want to do that  What would we do when we got home  Given more time there, wersquod only waste it, same as we did at work.Ms Marin mentioned families, but these are old hat nowadays and nobody can be bothered starting one, what with all the hassle and mess.No, the second report that caught my eye regarding what we do with our time was one that said people were being referred to counsellors and therapists for binge-watching box-sets and Netflix in their spare time. Some, indeed, were doing it at work, putting their jobs at risk, and the few that still had old-fashioned families were putting a strain on these too.So, therersquos your choice: work or binge-watch telly. You say: ldquoNot me, pal. Irsquod be oot walking the hills or writing a novel, ken  This news just in: no, you wouldnrsquot. You wouldnrsquot know what to do with your time.Experience teaches that the more time you have to do something the less you do it. Itrsquos just another of lersquos irritating conundrums. That said, we all want more time. Most of us have wasted our lives so far, but we still want more time so we can squander it.All that said, Irsquove never understood the eight-hour working day. Who decided that  Wersquove had it for more than  years and, for all the ldquoprogress, nothing has changed. Theyrsquove even taken away our lunch hours. But I havenrsquot time to go into that here.Stirring wordsITrsquoS time for a wee declaration. A Declaration of Arbroath, that is. Draw up in  by Scotlandrsquos then leaders, it contains probably the most stirring words of resistance and principle ever written by the human hand.To wit: ldquoAs long as but a hundred of us remain alive, never will we on any conditions be brought under English rule. It is in truth not for glory, nor riches, nor honours, that we are fighting, but for freedom ndash for that alone, which no honest man gives up but with le itself.The best thing about it is that it was written before people could leave comments below the line saying it was anti-English and deluded in thinking that Scotland could run its own affairs without funding through the Longshanks Formula.Seven hundred years on, the document is to go on display for the first time in  years, inspiring among foreign visitors romantic thoughts of national liberation and the accountability of monarchs to the people. Wersquove built mightier and mightier telescopes and still canrsquot see a thing.YouTube shows us film of UFOs, which are always rubbish, always blurred and always just reflected light from below. Any time you see a headline about le on Mars or wherever itrsquos always a bleedinrsquo microbe. Or maybe theyrsquore just too busy working an eight-hour day and binge-watching box-sets of Star Trek in their spare time.

title: Iain Macwhirter  Megxit means Megxit  It s time to abolish the monarchy
story: I couldnrsquot resist being drawn into the mysteries of palace le ndash the codes, the traditions, the high politics. It was brilliant public relations for the royal family. I found myself indulging in a new respect for Her Majesty herself,not the institution.Mrs Windsor has done a pretty good job in her six-and-a-bit decades on the throne, not just representing Britain but negotiating the dismantling of the British Empire in the s and s. Say what you like about Britainrsquos colonial past, but nothing became the Empire so much as the ending of it.She had the wisdom to realise, in the s, that to make the monarchy relevant, and justy the prodigious amounts of public money spent on its upkeep, there had to be a quid pro quo.The ldquoFirm, as she calls it, had to be seen to be ldquogiving something back through intense charitable activity and the grind of diplomatic intercourse. And, of course, simply ldquobeing there for the opening of bridges and hospitals, and for moments of national tragedy, like Aberfan.But the Queen is a product of a bygone age of deference, of patronage, of noblesse oblige. She embodies the virtues of duty, hard work and responsibility that defined the post-war ruling classes.These are anachronistic qualities in the age of celebrity. We now have an alternative royalty in the form of internet stars like the Kardashians, and Beyonce. This world has long held a fatal attraction to minor members of the royal brood, who aspire to the elite lestyle while lacking the means.Such has been the rather tawdry fate of Harry and Meghan. Megxit, and the disintegration of the Sussexesrsquo public image, would make a whole season of The Crown. Their departure from ldquosenior royal le has absolutely nothing to do with duty and everything to do with worldly aice.They clearly want to remain in the public eye, their celebrity wedding guest list confirmed that. They believe they can make a lot of money as influencers and sponsors. But they have found the duties and responsibilities of being part of the royal family uncongenial.In the words of Queen ndash the pop group that is ndash they want to break free. To which the British public says: fine. Do what you gotta to do. Polls show that the British public wish the Sussexes well in their new le.However, the deal is thatthey want to escape the paparazzi and the responsibilities of royalty, they must also give up its privileges. They must give up their royal titles and stop consuming vast amounts of public money.The renovation of their grace-and-favour home, Frogmore Cottage, cost the taxpayer pound. million. Their security costs around pound, a year. They receive millions from the revenues of royal estates, via Harryrsquos dad, Prince Charles.The financial taps should be turned off. There is no need, since Harryrsquos personal fortune is estimated at poundm and Meghan is also wealthy. To most of us this seems self-evident. And yoursquod expect Labour to be calling them out most loudly.The default position of the left used to be contempt for the flummery and waste of the royal family. They consume millions of pounds of public money that could be better used for foodbanks. The monarchy is regarded, rightly, as a feudal anachronism, the apex of privilege.But some Labour MPs, especially BAME ones, like Clive Lewis, seem to regard the Sussexes as a special kind of royalty. Far from condemning the behaviour of these soon-to-be ex-royals, theyrsquove been leaping to their defence. Meghan Markle is being portrayed as a victim rather than a social parasite. A victim of a racist media and a bigoted society.In a furious piece in the New York Times,columnist Afua Hirsch blamed deeply ingrained British racism for Meghanrsquos decision to ditch the Firm. ldquoHer treatment, she wrote, ldquohas proved what many of us have always known ... in this society racism will still follow you.Social media is fizzing with indignation at the allegedly racist treatment of Meghan. Oprah Winfrey has been fanning the flames across the pond. Racism has driven poor Meghan to seek refuge in Toronto.There is actually very little evidence of racism in the media treatment of Markle. The oft-quoted headline, ldquoshe was nearly straight out of Compton, may have been silly and wrong, but it wasnrsquot racist. The social and family background of a new member of the royal family is a legitimate matter of public interest.The instant sacking of disc jockey Danny Baker after his ldquomonkey tweet shows just how intolerant of racism the UK media has become. Criticism of Harry and Meghanrsquos hypocrisy in lecturing on the environment while relying on private jets is not racist.In the Sussexesrsquo resignation epistle there is no mention of racism. They clearly donrsquot like their treatment by the press. But their court actions against the media are about phone hacking and , not race.Meghan Markle was lionised by the press when she arrived on the scene three years ago. The media was fascinated and enchanted by this woke princess who was bringing the stuffy royal family into the st century.The coverage in all newspapers was little short of adulatory. Her feminism was widely praised she adorned the front page of Vogue her wedding had the full -inside-pages treatment.Meghanrsquos arrival was seen as a signicant moment in the progress towards equality and ersity in Britain. Her departure comes as a blow to minority groups which saw her as a torch-bearer for anti-racism and anti-sexism. As a royal she had a unique  now she is just another self-obsessed celebrity.And the royalsrsquo behaviour following the Epstein scandal is a serious blow to The Firm. It is clear that the monarchy, as it stands, is no longer viable. It will have to downsize to immunise itself from scandals like this in future.Questions about the anachronistic constitutional role of the Queen can no longer be avoided.She is head of state, a formal role of course, but one that nearly became highly political during the Brexit crisis last year. There was a real possibility that the Queen might have had to decide whether or not to endorse a caretaker prime minister.This monarch should be the last to have any formal role in the constitution. The Crown should no longer be seen as above politics. The hereditary principle should play no part in our democracy.It goes without saying that therersquos no place for royalty in Scotland. The Scottish National Party needs to reassess its historical support for the Queen. Alex Salmond called her the ldquoQueen of Scots, and the  White Paper envisaged a role for the monarch in Scotland after independence. This is surely no longer tenable.If Scotland is to become independent, there should be no question of a hereditary head of state. And there is surely no place for celebrity airheads like the Sussexes.

title: meet-new-generation-baby-boomers-scotlands-islands
story: Spanning just  miles by six, perched on the edge of the Western Isles and with a single-track road as its main highway, Barrarsquos largely unoccupied hilly interior is offset by sandy beaches hugged by the grassy machair.Picture-postcard pretty, remote, lonely, very windswept and loved by tourists, it is perhaps the last place on Earth that might seem likely to be gripped by a population explosion.Yet the patter of very tiny feet is set to sound very loudly across the island.At least  women are said to be currently pregnant ndash a remarkable number on an island with a population of just over ,.Not only that, but two years ago the number of babies also hit double digits with  births.ldquoMaybe itrsquos something in the water or too many power cuts, says one bemused local currently counting the weeks to the arrival of his second Barra baby.But while the baby boom has sparked countless ldquonudge-nudge jokes, the tiny Barra does not appear to be the only one of Scotlandrsquos scattered Hebridean islands to be experiencing a leap in little people.Despite recent statistics, reported in The Herald on Sunday last week, that suggest the Western Isles are tottering on the brink of a major depopulation crisis almost on a par with the historic Clearances, it seems some islands are facing a dferent kind of problem ndash trying to find enough nursery space to cope.In North Uist, Emily Durie looks out of her kitchen window over her yard where chickens peck and her children happily play towards a glassy sea loch and spectacular sunsets.Her idyllic view is a long way from the hustle and bustle of Manchester where she used to live, and hundreds of miles from her family in the northeast of England.Durie arrived on the island with her architect husband Alex, , in the grip of a March storm just over two years ago to a house theyrsquod never seen before. There was no internet, no phone line and only the warm welcome of their new North Uist neighbours to chase away fears that relocating to a west coast island with a -months-old baby may have been a mistake.Yet, she insists, therersquos no better place to raise Elsie, now three, and her two-year-old brother, Henry.ldquoThere are plenty of children here, says Durie, . A primary school teacher who specialises in outdoor learning, she is helping nursery schools across the Uists increase capacity by introducing outdoor classroom space.ldquoIf all the children across the Uists were to take up their free childcare entitlement, the nurseries wouldnrsquot have the capacity, she points out.Around  miles across the Sea of the Hebrides in Eigg, former music journalist Sarah Boden, , has quit city le for sheep farming and raising son Arlo, four, and -months-old Ness with her musician partner Johnny Lynch, , on the island where she grew up.Two years ago, news of a babyrsquos birth on Eigg made national headlines after its arrival pushed the number of residents over  for the first time in the islandrsquos recent history. Ness was one of three babies born last year and another is due in April while a new family with two children is set to arrive in April.ldquoPart of the attraction is the people here, says Boden. ldquoItrsquos egalitarian, everyone has a similar standard of living which contributes to the community bond.ldquoIn summer therersquos so much going on. People are attracted to Eigg for its music events while in winter itrsquos more community-focused.But there are serious issues that young families have to consider, she warns. For example, the closest secondary schoolrsquos location in Mallaig means children leave Eigg for two weeks at a time to board on the mainland.ldquoThe doctor comes every Tuesday, sothe children have a raging temperature you just have to work around it, she adds. ldquoItrsquos part and parcel of living here.Eiggrsquos population boom is being attributed in part to the  community buyout. ldquoThings are happening now, says Maggie Fyffe, secretary of the Isle of Eigg Heritage Trust. The island is a bit more exciting than it used to be and that has attracted young people back.ldquoItrsquos a wonderful place to raise children. People donrsquot have the same kind of lsquostranger dangerrsquo, parents can let their children out the door and not worry.ldquoThe children know everyone and they are never excluded. If therersquos a ceilidh, the children come too.ldquoBut the lack of housing is a big problem.It all sounds buoyant, yet recent statistics have made grim reading.The number of babies born last year at the Western Isles hospital is said to have slumped to  compared to  four years before, and in the past  years, a dozen of the  islands of the Outer Hebrides have become officially uninhabited.Projections suggest a % population decline for Lewis and Harris by , while ndash despite evidence of the baby boom ndash Barra is supposedly braced for a % slide in its numbers.It has been suggested that the Western Islesrsquo overall population will fall from , in  to , by  ndash a projected decline of , people over the -year period.According to Theona Morrison, founder and Director of CoDel, a project which supports enterprise and young people, statistics and birth records suggesting a downward sht across islandsrsquo populations may not always tell the full story.ldquoThe authorities must recognise itrsquos not all one way. There are places like Barra where there has been a real boost in population numbers. Itrsquos worth remembering that not all babies on the islands are born there. Some may be parents ing to the islands with lsquoready-madersquo children that donrsquot appear in the birth statistics.ldquoOthers leave the islands to have their children in hospital in Inverness or Glasgow.ldquoThe pre-school and primary school numbers are what we should be looking at. For example, in North Uist alone therersquos a pre-school mums and tots group that has around  children.ldquoThere have been six sets of twins in the last two years between Benbecula and North Uist.The boost in population was recognised in September in a statement from the Islands Revival, a project supported by the Scottish Government-funded Sefari Responsive Opportunity Initiative and led by the James Hutton Institute and SRUC.Its Islands Revival declaration stated: ldquoWe affirm that there is credible evidence of lsquogreen shootsrsquo of population turnaround in the Scottish islands, which as yet does not show up in official statistics.ldquoThis is illustrated by a number of examples of population growth in islands. It is also indicated by a more positive discourse on population change in island communities.ldquoIt is supported by the changing perceptions of younger, economically active people, especially out-migrant islanders, who increasingly consider their birthplace as a place toto, and at an earlier stage in their lives. Connectivityis playing an important role in popularising this attitude.ldquoIt is important to acknowledge that the demographic aspirations of island communities are not necessarily lsquogrowthrsquo, but rather sustainability, renewal, or restored viability, without risk to social, cultural and environmental assets.The project has also collected its own population statistics which show a % jump in population in West Harris between  and , a doubling in Eiggrsquos numbers since , and growth in Westray in Orkney, Iona and Ulva.Tiny Kerera in the Inner Hebrides, close to Oban, is also said to have doubled in numbers since .Meanwhile, on South Uist, numbers have just been boosted by one ndash although the birth wonrsquot show up on official birth register for the islands.Samantha MacCormick, , recently ed from working in Australia after six years and delivered her lb .oz baby son Darradh in hospital in Glasgow on Thursday.Alongside was her sister Christina Morrison, , who also ed to South Uist after living in Glasgow to raise Finn, three, and one-year-old April with husband Kevin, .ldquoIn Glasgow, we were spending our time working. Every chance we got we were getting out of the city, says Morrison, a marketing executive.ldquoWe thought why not reverse that and live surrounded by beautul scenery and enjoying the quality of le we want ldquoWhen I was growing up Irsquod head out of the house in the morning and explore. My mum had no idea where I was but she knew I was safe.ldquoTherersquos a freedom here. We are a five-minute walk from the beach.ldquoItrsquos a special place.

title: scotlands-youth-hostels-get-new-image-find
story: But now designers from the upmarket Scots firm Graven have been brought in to carry out a pound, upgrade to ndash a youth hostel.In a radical move away from the hostel image of worn lino and draughty dorms, the downstairs area of the organisationrsquos -bed Edinburgh hostel is being transformed.It is going from what Graven boss Ross Hunter says ldquomight have been a community centre from the s into a cleverly integrated space with sales, dining and chill-out areas flowing effortlessly into each other.Lighting, soft furnishings and decor have all been thought through so the hostel can compete with some of the most modern spaces in the capital.To keep the budget down the designers have kept much of the original layout and even some of the furniture but applied some expensive modern finishes to give it the urban chic they are renowned for.Hostelling Scotlandndash as the Scottish Youth Hostels Association has now been rebranded ndash says it is part of a major new drive to modernise, upgrade and allow its hostels to compete and win in a crowded accommodation market. HS is one of the biggest players in the Scottish tourism market, with  hostels across Scotland.It accommodates , people a year and has a turnover of pound million, bringing poundm a year the Scottish visitor economy.HS chief executive Margo Paterson admits it was the ldquofunky approach of the designers that led her organisation to Graven, and Hunter says it was his personal memory of, and enthusiasm for, hostelling that convinced him to take on the challenge of upgrading a youth hostel.He now has designs on helping to modernise the rest of the HS estate, talking enthusiastically about designing a special Scottish bunk bed that could be used throughout the HS estate.Both emphasised that the unique nature of hostelling, where travellers get the chance to mix and meet, was key to their thinking.ldquoBecause Edinburgh Central is our flagship hostel and competition is fierce in the capital we wanted to get it right, so we looked to Graven, said Paterson.ldquoTheyrsquore an award-winning Scottish design company ndash what attracted us to them is that they have a great deal of experience in the hospitality world, we are a national hostelling organisation so both ourselves and Graven were really keen to come up with an exciting new design that would really best represent our ongoing modernisation.ldquoTheyrsquore just funky and they have such great ideas.Fascinating archive pictures from Hostelling Scotland and artistsrsquo impressions of the new Edinburgh hostel show how hostelling and hostellers in Scotland have changed over the years.In the s, many hostels were simple wood-clad buildings, such as the well-known Glencoe premises.Riders would use hostels as touring stops, while school groups such Kilmarnock Academy would use them as a holiday base.Warming your knees at the enormous stove was classic entertainment in the s at Crianlarich, and washing facilities at those such as Rowardennan were primitive.Other hostels were in converted big houses, with domestic touches such as fireplaces in the rooms at Oban still evident. But an innovative approach to design has reared its head in the past with the Torridon Hostel built in the s, which still has a touch of mid-century style.The refurbished Glen Nevis hostel has plenty of style, and the new Edinburgh onersquos public areas in the artistsrsquo impressions show the new look of hostels and hostelling.The Edinburgh transformation follows last yearrsquos pound.m upgrade of HSrsquos flagship Glen Nevis hostel, used by thousands each year as a base to climb Ben Nevis and explore the surrounding area.The old wooden building was given a major facelt and an all-new interior, including en-suite bathrooms, twin rooms, giant windows to take advantage of stunning views, and a glossy modern feel. Other hostels are beginning to feel the wind of change, with the barracks-like Inverness hostel getting a smart new lounge and cafe bar area with features such as a water refill station.Hostels modernised recently include Aberdeen, where more private rooms have been installed. There have also been upgrades at Loch Ossian, Achmelvich Beach, Oban and Lochranza on Arran.Ross Hunter, who founded Graven in the s with his partner Janice Kirkpatrick, is delighted to be helping Hostelling Scotland move into a new era.His organisation is better known for designing upmarket interiors at the likes of the Blythswood Square hotel in Glasgow, the VIP lounges at Anfield stadium, and brand and image development at Royal Bank of Scotland premises.Hunter spent many youthful holidays in hostels, starting in  when he paid p a night at the Glen Doll hostel in Angus before walking over Jockrsquos Road to Inverey on Deeside and paying just p to stay there.He said the Edinburgh hostel, a s city-centre office building converted to a hostel in , had become ldquoout of touch with visitorsrsquo expectations: ldquoIt had become a bit institutional looking ndash it might have been a community centre from the s.The challenge was to upgrade it to compete with budget hotels and other cut-price offers for visitors who wanted a more sophisticated city experience, without ruining the communal feel which sets it apart from hotels and Airbnb.He said a cleverly-designed feature dubbed the ldquoGreat Wall of China running along the space managed to unite its dferent uses, while high-end tiles and stone provided the gloss it needed. ldquoIrsquove got fond memories of Scottish hostelling, he said. ldquoA key reason why people stay in hostels is the social experience.ldquoYou meet people who are like-minded ndash whether theyrsquore the same age or not is irrelevant as theyrsquore there because they want the same kind of experience. That opportunity to speak to fellow hostellers is still there and the thing thatrsquos special about hostelling in Scotland is that it provides a really safe environment to have that kind of engagement.The project has fired his imagination. ldquoWe would love the opportunity of extending that kind of thinking into other locations into other hostels too ... we could even design a new Scottish hostel bunk they could use across their estate, he said.HS has been steadily modernising ndash chores for guests were scrapped in the s, alcohol started being sold in , and ldquowardens are now managers ndash but the arrival of Paterson as boss of the organisation accelerated the change, including the new name.Paterson has said HS needs to be in cities, where it has to compete with hotel chains, because that provides surpluses that help pay for upkeep and development of more remote hostels, which the organisation remains deeply committed to.It is also holding true to the ldquoyouth element of the original name, with moves such as the appointment of the first youth trustee, Sophie Bell, . More young trustees are being sought, and a pound, Explorer Fund has been set up to fund trips for youth groups.Paterson added: ldquoWersquoll never be Premier Inn but thatrsquos what our members and guests love about us.The one thing thatrsquos consistent is our welcome and our good customer service but when you go into each hostel therersquos always something a bit dferent.

title: pupils-crammed-like-sardines-primary-schools-pushed-limits
story: Since , hundreds of schools have closed across the country with  fewer schools overall now than there were a decade ago.Dozens of schools, the majority of them primaries, are now having to accommodate more than the maximum number of pupils they were designed for, with some teachers having to use reading rooms, family rooms and Portakabins as routine classroom alternatives.In some cases schools are bulging with up to  per cent more children than they are meant to accommodate, sparking concerns over the impact on their safety and standard of education they receive.Critics have accused the Scottish Government of failing on education and said children are being ldquocrammed in like sardines.Beatrice Wishart, the Liberal Democrats spokeswoman for education, said the data showed that education was not a priority for Nicola Sturgeonrsquos government, and added: "Its a far cry from fostering an environment thatrsquos conducive to learning."While the number of over-capacity secondary schools has reduced in the last  years, from  in  to  in  , the number or primaries schools has risen with  primaries now catering for  per cent or more of the pupils they were designed for, compared with  in .Analysis of the latest education statistics published by the Scottish government show the number of P- children in classes with  or fewer students has also fallen in the last decade.This is despite the Governmentrsquos goal of reducing class sizes for youngsters in the first three years of primary to  pupils or less.In , .% of students in their first three years of education were being taught in classes with up to  pupils, but last year, it was just .% of P- students.In  South Morningside Primary in Edinburgh had one teacher for  P children.Shetland MSP Wishart said: "Schools across the country are under-resourced and in some cases children are packed in like sardines.ldquoThe number of pupils being taught in super-size classes has soared on the SNPrsquos watch while some buildings simply arenrsquot designed to cope with the numbers of children they are accommodating.ldquoThis is the case in primary schools especially, where some large primary schools are in the region of % over capacity. Itrsquos a far cry from fostering an environment thatrsquos conducive to learning and bigger classes make it harder to close the attainment gap.ldquoEducation is supposed to be the Scottish Governmentrsquos number one priority, but few people believe that any more."Teachers union EIS has also raised concerns about over-stretched schools, and said it was "unacceptable" that children and teachers were being forced to work in such an environment.They blamed the rising strain on local authority budgets and said childrens education would be impacted.A spokesman for EIS told The Herald on title: speedo-diplomacy-diving-coldest-place-earth
story: A WEEK ago Lewis Pugh, midway through his training camp on the Isle of Lewis for the pioneering endurance swim he is about to do in sub-zero East Antarctica, opened his door in Tong to a storm. The winds, he recalls, were around  miles an hour andrainwas coming in horizontally.This was the weather the ocean advocate and UN Patron of the Oceans had come to the Outer Hebrides for. It didnrsquot daunt him. Pugh, who was the first man to long-distance swim in all seven oceans, across the North Pole and in a glacial lake on Mount Everest, has known more terrying extremes.ldquoThe wind was so strong it was dficult to close the front door, the -year-old says. ldquoI realised this really was simulating the conditions Irsquom going to find in Antarctica.Rather than swim in the sea, and ldquorisk othersrsquo lives, such as those of the RNLI, he headed with three training companions for a loch on the island, and found what he describes as ldquosome of the most atrocious conditions I have ever experienced.ldquoIt was the type of waters you would only go intoa child was drowning, he says.The environmental campaigner, who has been swimming the worldrsquos oceans for more than three decades, believes the world is in a situation that requires the urgency we might give to a child drowning. Itrsquos that sense of alarm that is driving him to swim across a supraglacial lake in Antarctica on January  ndash a feat he hopes will help persuade governments to create a network of marine protected areasaround Antarctica and tackle climate change. It is what is behind what has been described as his ldquoSpeedo diplomacy.Pughrsquos aim, he says, is about ldquotrying to raise awareness of climate change. But he admits: ldquoWe are so far past that. If you are not aware of climate change yoursquore either an ostrich or an Australian politician.The kilometre swim he is about to do in an Antarctic area which holds the record for the lowest temperatures on Earth ndash and in just his Speedos ndash is all about calling on world leaders to have their own courage.One of the reasons Pugh chose Lewis as his base for training was to send out a political message. ldquoIt was because our futures will be determined in Glasgow, at the COP UN conference on climate change, he says. ldquoAnd I donrsquot say that lightly. We canrsquot kick the can down the road any longer. COP in Madrid was a bitter disappointment. All roads now lead to Glasgow.ldquoThe UK Government is going to have to do some very heavy lting. They must use all their diplomatic effort to ensure all  nations commit to ensuring we take urgent action. We have to do everything we can now to fix the problem. Andwe donrsquot the scenes we are seeing now in Australia are going to be common.He also chose it because the Outer Hebrides offered the right water conditions. ldquoWe felt that these were the very best we could find, which would not be as radical as Antarctica, but would prepare me for Antarctica. We were looking for rough, wild seas and very strong winds. Lewis offered not only seas of C, but lochs at C.These conditions are, of course, in no way as extreme as in Antarctica. ldquoThere the water will be zero degrees, he points out. ldquoThe air temperature will probably be -C. Itrsquos terrying. East Antarctica is the coldest place on Earth.ldquoIrsquom also  now and the science is very clear. The older you get, the less tolerant you get to cold water. But Irsquom so determined to get Antarctica protected. My determination is stronger than the indference of any political leader.Pugh has swum in water that is colder, when, for example, he took on a -metre stretch of the Ross Sea where the water was -.C and the air was -C. He recalls: ldquoYou pull your arm out of water at -.C and itrsquos dropping then to -C so you want to put it back in to warm it back up.His first major sub-zero swim was across the North Pole in . ldquoIn those days, many political leaders were denying what was happening in the Arctic and Irsquod been visiting it for a number of years, he recalls. ldquoIrsquod seen the sea ice melting.The salt water at the North Pole is also -.C. ldquoWater is an interesting substance, he says. ldquoBetween C and C itrsquos a liquid. Below zero itrsquos a solid. There are certain tipping points at which you donrsquot know whatrsquos going to happen, and they have a profound impact on the human body.ldquoI remember standing at the Arctic on the sea ice. Irsquom about about to jump into the water and itrsquos completely black, and Irsquom realising thatthings go wrong now I wonrsquot be alive in a few minutes.He still finds it terrying, even now after all the cold-water swims he has done.In , Pugh swam the -mileof the English Channel in  days. ldquoMy aim was to get the British Government to understand how important it was to protect our waters from industrial fishing, drilling and other processes, he says.Of the waters around the UK, he points out: ldquoOnly seven square kilometres are protected.The swim was unrelenting, says Pugh. ldquoI wanted the Government to commit to protecting % by , and finally, at the end, Michael Gove came down to the beach and the UK Government committed. But I wish they would have done that before I started the swim because it was hard.However, this Antarctic swim will have a dferent intensity. ldquoYou know yoursquore on the edge of le and death, he says.Pugh, who was born in the UK and lives in Cape Town, does what he does in spite of the risk because he has what he describes as ldquopurpose. For him, there was no damascene moment, just a growing awareness built over his career. ldquoThirty-three years is a very long career for a sport, he says. ldquoBut in terms of the le of planet Earth itrsquos but a nanosecond ndash and in that time Irsquove seen massive changes.The biggest changes, he says, have been in the Arctic and the Antarctic. ldquoItrsquos been seeing the melting of the sea ice in the Arctic and also the rise in water temperature. When I did my first swim in the Arctic, in the island of Spitsbergen, the water was C in August. I went back there two years ago. The water was C.Pugh wants not only to highlight this warming, but to negotiate the creation of a network of marine protected areas around Antarctica.The ice breakers. How Scotlands ice swimmers taught me to love the cold.ldquoThe swims take % of my time. Itrsquos the negotiations afterwards which are % of the work. We negotiated an MPA in the Ross Sea in . Itrsquos the biggest protected area in the world, . million square kilometres.ldquoWersquore now trying to build another three. That involves shuttling backwards and forwards to Moscow, to Beijing, other nations. The swim is not over until the MPAs are set up and working. This could be a four-year campaign.He challenges us all to look at what we ourselves are doing. ldquoWe have to ask ourselves one simple question, he says. ldquoWhether you are a government, a business, or a normal person hellip is your response to the climate emergency adequate Talk to Pugh and you get a dferent sense of what a personal adequate response might be. For him, itrsquos taking his own body to its limits, risking death. ldquoI have no desire to die, he says. ldquoI do these swims because I love le, and not just human le, all le. I donrsquot know what  I can do now to draw the worldrsquos attention to what is happening.ldquoIrsquove been swimming with this message for over  years. I donrsquot know what  I can do to shake the lapels of world leaders and get them to understand we have no more time. Time has run out.Pugh extols the pleasures of his Lewis camp. One of these was the unexpected community of swimmers he found there. ldquoWe found a whole community of local swimmers on the Isle of Lewis, which the swimming community in the world didnrsquot know about ndash and they were amazing. Every day it would be myself and Max Holloway, Stacey Holloway [who run guide and coach company WayOutside Ltd] and this guy Colin Macleod.ldquoColin would rope in every local and on some days we would have more people. One day Ben Fogle visited and we had .ldquoOn the Isle of Lewis it gets light at .am and dark by .pm, he says. ldquoImagine you get up at . and now yoursquore going to jump into a freezing loch. Thatrsquos not easy. But I can tell you something ndash itrsquos easy when yoursquove got  locals jumping in with you.On the day of the mph winds, Pugh didnrsquot swim alone. His three training companions jumped into the water with him. ldquoThey all came in with me. And I looked at them as I was doing this, swimming in these atrocious conditions.ldquoI was swallowing a lot of water, so I just did  minutes. I looked at them and thought, lsquoWhere  on Earth would you find these type of people  They are beautul peoplersquo.

title: scottish-secretary-rules-indyref2-even-snp-win-holyrood-majority-2021
story: Alister Jack said a Tory government at Westminster would refuse to grant Holyrood the power to hold Indyref for a generation or even for Nicola Sturgeonrsquos letime.He told the BBC Scotlandrsquos Sunday Politics that position would not change eventhe SNP repeated their electoral feat of  and won a second Holyrood majority in .He said: ldquoWe do not think that  is the time to start having more referendums.This is a U-turn on his publicly stated position in November, when he said an SNP majority in  would constitute a ldquodemocratic mandate for Indyref negotiations.Mr Jack also said it was ldquounacceptable for Holyrood to have permanent referendum powers, as it would plunge Scotland into a series of constitutional ldquoneverendums.He said he had advised Mr Johnson to deliver a ldquorebuttal to Ms Sturgeon, something she herself has said she expects.THe SNP said his flip-flopping on the issue was "embarrassing".In the wake of the SNPrsquos general election gains last month, Ms Sturgeon has insisted she has a mandate to hold Indyref later this year in order to revisit the No vote of .However she has also suggested the  Scotland Act could be overhauled to give Holyrood permanent powers to hold constitutional referendums when it chose.The Prime Minister is expected to rebuff both suggestions within days.Mr Jack said: ldquoA Section  order is a constitutional matter. What the SNP have asked for in the letter Nicola Sturgeon has sent is the right to choose when the referendum should be.ldquoWe are standing up for the people who are voting for the Unionist parties.ldquoItrsquos about once in a generation, once in a letime. Thatrsquos what people voted for.ldquoI think that wersquove had  years where Scotlandrsquos been in discussion or having referendums.ldquoIt hasnrsquot done our economy any good. Wersquore slower than the English economy. Itrsquos not good for jobs.Pressed on whether Mr Johnson would refuse to give the Scottish Government a Section  order eventhe SNP won an absolute majority on a manesto promise of Indyref, Mr Jack said: ldquoConstitutionally we are coming out of the European Union. We think whatrsquos right now is that we have a period where we settle down.ldquoWe do not think that  is the time to start having more referendums. Theyrsquore very isive for our society. I think the time now is for us to pull together as one United Kingdom.Asked what the SNP would have to do to get a mandate for Indyref, the Scottish Secretary said: ldquoLetrsquos see the benefits of Brexit. Theyrsquove talked Brexit down as a disaster. Letrsquos seethe worldrsquos still spinning on the st of February and how things can be good for Scotland.Askedhis message to Nicola Sturgeonrsquos was that her successor or successorrsquos successor would have to wait for Indyref, he said: ldquoYeah, a generation or a letime has passed. Letrsquos see the benefits of Brexit for the United Kingdom first.On Ms Sturgeonrsquos request for permanent referendum powers, he went on: ldquoThat is unacceptable. Irsquove written to the Prime Minister on this subject this week.ldquoHersquoll be replying very soon to Nicola Sturgeonrsquos letter of the th of December.ldquoItrsquos absolutely the case that constitutional matters are reserved. They must remain with the UK parliament, the same way defence must remain, the same way foreign policy must remain."It would be wrong for us to give the right to the Scottish Parliament to set the referendums and the context and the timings whenever they wanted for the simple reason that Scotland would then be plunged into neverendums, and thatrsquos not good for us, not good for the economy. ldquoAskedthat was what the Prime Minister would tell Ms Sturgeon this week, Mr Jack said: ldquoNicola Sturgeon has said she fully expects a rebuttal from the Prime Minister to her letter.ldquoMy advice to him is certainly to say that.He went on: ldquoWe have a mandate to say No to a second independence referendum because the Edinburgh Agreement [paving the way for the  referendum] was signed in  by Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond."In that agreement it said both parties will uphold the result of the referendum and respect it. They havenrsquot respected the result of the  referendum and they havenrsquot respected the result of the  one.In fact, the Edinburgh Agreement does not include a cast-iron commitment by the Scottish Government to uphold and respect the result, but a more ambiguous aspiration that the result will be fair and clear enough to command respect.The text states the UK and Scottish ldquogovernments are agreed that the referendum shouldhellip deliver a fair test and a decisive expression of the views of people in Scotland and a result that everyone will respect.The governments also ldquolook forward to a referendum that is legal and fair producing a decisive and respected outcome.But the SNP could still argue that, despite those high hopes, respect for the result has proved ephemeral because of Brexit.Mr Jackrsquos ruling out of a Section  order eventhere is another SNP majority at Holyrood is a complete reversal of Mr Jackrsquos position in November.Then, he was askedthe SNP winning most of Scotlandrsquos  seats in the general election would give it a democratic mandate for a Section  order, and replied: ldquoNo.Asked why not, he said: ldquoBecause the democratic mandate for a Section  order is a matter for . Wersquoll see whether or not the Scottish National Party get a majority then.ldquoI mean the Scottish National Party - not in collaboration with other parties, not in any alliances - but a Scottish National Party majority, which is what Ruth Davidson pointed out some months ago.In June last year, Ms Davidson, while still leader of the Scottish Tories, said an outright majority would be needed to begin negotiations on Indyref.She told the BBC: "If she [Ms Sturgeon] puts it in a [Holyrood] manesto that shes going to hold another referendum and she wins a majority outright, then she can negotiate with theUK government in the same way as happened last time.Asked about his previous comment today, Mr Jack ly claimed he had prefixed it with ldquoRuth Davidson has said.He said: ldquoIn that interview, I made it very clear that it was a once in a letime, once in a generation, vote that we had, and I didnrsquot feel a generation or a letime had passed.ldquoI think we have to take  as a campaign for the Conservatives and the other Unionist parties in Scotland to press hard as they can to press the case for the Union.SNP Shadow Scottish Secretary Mhairi Black said Mr Jackrsquos U-turn was ldquoembarrassing.She said: ldquoThe SNP won a landslide victory in last monthrsquos general election - winning % on a mandate for an independence referendum, while the Tories lost more than half their MPs.ldquoThey stood on a  of stopping Scotlandrsquos right to choose and were humiliated at the polls - the Tories have no mandate whatsoever to block Scottish democracy.ldquoWhatever your views on independence, we can all agree that Scotlandrsquos future must be Scotlandrsquos choice ndash not Boris Johnsonrsquos or his cronies.ldquoScotland voted overwhelmingly to remain in the EU and has rejected Brexit at every opportunity. And despite all the bluster from Westminster politicians like Alister Jack, we all know that a fresh referendum on Scotlandrsquos future is in demand.

title: POLITICS WATCH  It s the Andrew Marr Show  starring actor James McAvoy
story: He began yesterdayrsquos show by saying that it looked like ordinary political le had resumed after a frenzied year dealing with Brexit. Not so.ldquoBoris Johnson has a formidable task drawing up a new trade agreement with the EU ahead of him, there is a real royal crisis, while a shattered opposition still havenrsquot managed to regroup, find a new leader and a new way ahead.ldquoApologiesyoursquod hoped it was all going quiet. Itrsquos as wild as ever!As it happened, Marr had a guest who was in every sense a genuine box office draw.The BBCrsquos Sunday show is meant to be the television equivalent of a Sunday newspaper, with lighter material balancing the heavier political fare.Previous arts guests have included the director Sam Mendes, talking about his movie , Scots actor Brian Cox, the musician James Blunt, and the saxophonist Jess Gillam.The arts filling in the politics sandwich yesterday was one James McAvoy. The Glasgow-born actor is earning toasty reviews for his performance as Cyrano de Bergerac at the Playhouse Theatre in London. Directed by Jamie Lloyd and adapted by Martin Crimp, it is a stripped-back version of Rostandrsquos nineteenth century play. It is so back to basics there is no set, no period costumes, no props, and controversially, no large nose for Cyrano.McAvoy was fine with that. Itrsquos not about the nose, he insisted. ldquoIt is described as being hideous, ugly, all these things. It never is. Itrsquos usually a bit bulbous, itrsquos maybe a bit long, but I think there is always somebody out there who would fancy a bit of that.Now, you might think being on a politics show would involve talking about current affairs. It depends on the guest, however. Some are comfortable talking about politics, others steer clear.Anyone tuning in yesterday to hear McAvoyrsquos hot take on indyref,indeed he even has one, would have been disappointed. Perhaps Marr chose not to ask, or McAvoy did not say anything of note. Either way, the subject failed to make an appearance.The liveliest moment came when Marr brought up Martin Scorsesersquos comments about superhero movies. The director of Raging Bull and The Irishman put the CGI cat among the pigeons recently when he said special effects- laden superhero movies were not proper cinema because there was no genuine jeopardy.He told Empire magazine: ldquoHonestly, the closest I can think of them, as well made as they are, with actors doing the best they can under the circumstances, is theme parks. It isnrsquot the cinema of human beings trying to convey emotional, psychological experiences to another human being.Among McAvoyrsquos most famous roles is Charles Xavier in the X-Men movies. His reaction to Scorsesersquos comments ldquoHersquos Martin Scorsese, he can say what he likes. But I would also hope that hersquos watched every single superhero movie. Irsquove watched some of them and they are dross, and Irsquove watched some of them that have moved me to tears, made me really feel and think. Some of them have terried me and scared me in ways that his [Scorsesersquos] movies have never done.With that it was back to the studio and politics as usual. Even here there was an attempt to inject some drama into proceedings. Marrrsquos final guest was Emily Thornberry, the Shadow Foreign Secretary, and one of those hoping to be the new Labour leader.By today, in common with the other candidates, Thornberry must have secured the backing of at least  MPs MEPs to proceed to the next round of the contest. By yesterday she was still short by more than half. Tick tock.Ms Thornberry said she was ldquofairly confident she would get enough votes. She put her slow start in the race down to the party being in a general state of ldquogrief after the disastrous showing in the General Election.Thus far, the Labour leadership contest has been a ldquoprolier than thou contest to see who has the strongest working class roots. In keeping with this, Marr asked Ms Thornberry about her now infamous  tweet in which she posted a picture of a white van outside a house that was draped with St Georgersquos flags. You appeared to be sneering, he said.I wasnt, said Thornberry. ldquoThe truth is I was brought up on a council estate, in a house that looks very similar to [that], my brother was a builder until he had an accident. Irsquove got a sister who is a bus driver. I donrsquot sneer at people hellip I am a successful woman but I have had a struggle getting here.Sounds like the beginnings of a beautul film script. Ah, but who would play Ms Thornberry
